title: Smoothness of commutative Hopf algebras

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Hopf algebras, most generally in a semisimple abelian symmetric monoidal category, are here supposed to be commutative but not to be of finitetype, and their (equivariant) smoothness are discussed. Given a Hopf algebra $H$ in a category such as above, it is proved that the following are equivalent: (i) $H$ is smooth as an algebra; (ii) $H$ is smooth as an $H$-comodule algebra; (iii) the product morphism $S_{H}^{2}\left(H^{+}\right) \rightarrow H^{+}$defined on the 2nd symmetric power is monic. Working over a field $k$ of characteristic zero, we prove: (1) every ordinary Hopf algebra, i.e., such in the category Vec of vector spaces, satisfies the equivalent conditions (i)-(iii) and some others; (2) every Hopf algebra in the category sVec of super-vector spaces has a certain property that is stronger than (i). In the case where char $k=p>0$, there are shown weaker properties of ordinary Hopf algebras and of Hopf algebras in sVec or in the ind-completion $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$ of the Verlinde category.


Key Words: Commutative Hopf algebra, Smooth, Equivariantly smooth, Locally complete intersection, Hochschild cohomology, André-Quillen (co)homology

Mathematics Subject Classification (2010): 16T05, 14L15

## 1. Introduction: background and main theorems

This paper discusses smoothness of commutative Hopf algebras not necessarily of finite type, which include commutative Hopf-algebra objects in general categories with appropriate properties. We thus say "of finite type" for "finitely generated". We have three main theorems which are explicitly formulated in the following subsections.
1.1. Smoothness of ordinary Hopf algebras. Let us work over an arbitrary field $k$, and vector spaces, linear maps and tensor products mean those over $k$. Algebras and Hopf algebras, which indicate those over $k$, are supposed to be commutative unless otherwise stated.

An algebra is said to be smooth (over $k$ ) [30, Section 9.3.1], if given an algebra $R$ and a nilpotent ideal $I$ of $R$, every algebra map $f: A \rightarrow R / I$ can lift to some algebra map $g: A \rightarrow R$, i.e., the $g$, composed with the natural projection $R \rightarrow R / I$, turns into $f$. It is known that in the case where $A$ is Noetherian, the condition is equivalent to saying that $A$ is geometrically regular, i.e., it remains regular after base extension to the algebraic closure of $k$. The definition above is suited when we discuss, as we will do, smoothness of algebras not necessarily of finite type. As another advantage the definition, which concerns algebras in the symmetric monoidal category Vec of vector spaces, can directly extend to those in general categories with appropriate properties. For example, given a Hopf algebra $H$, we can (and we do) discuss smoothness of $H$-comodule algebras, i.e., algebras in the symmetric monoidal category of (right or left) $H$-comodules. We say that an $H$ comodule algebra $A$ is $H$-smooth (or equivariantly smooth, without referring to the

Hopf algebra) if given an $H$-comodule algebra and a nilpotent $H$-costable ideal $I$ of $R$, every $H$-colinear algebra map $A \rightarrow R / I$ can lift to such a map $A \rightarrow R$. Here and in what follows, comodules are meant to be right comodules unless otherwise stated. Our interest is in the case where $A$ is $H$, itself.

Let $H$ be a Hopf algebra. Let $H^{+}=\operatorname{Ker}\left(\varepsilon_{H}: H \rightarrow k\right)$ denote the augmentation ideal, and let $S_{H}^{2}\left(H^{+}\right)$denote the 2 nd symmetric power of the $H$-module $H^{+}$. Let us consider the conditions:
(a) $H$ is smooth,
(b) $H$ is $H$-smooth,
(c) $H$ is $Q$-smooth for every quotient Hopf algebra $Q$ of $H$ such that $H$ is coflat as a $Q$-comodule, i.e., the co-tensor product $H \square_{Q}$ (see (2.11)) is exact as a functor,
(d) the $H$-linear map

$$
\mu_{H}: S_{H}^{2}\left(H^{+}\right) \rightarrow H^{+}
$$

which is induced by the product $H^{+} \otimes_{H} H^{+} \rightarrow H^{+}, a \otimes_{H} b \mapsto a b$ is injective,
(e) $H$ is geometrically reduced, i.e., it remains reduced after the base extension to the algebraic closure of $k$,
and in addition, in case char $k=p>0$,
(f) the Frobenius map

$$
F_{H}: k^{1 / p} \otimes H \rightarrow H, \quad F_{H}\left(a^{1 / p} \otimes h\right)=a h^{p}
$$

is injective, where $k^{1 / p} \otimes$ presents the base extension along the isomorphism $k \rightarrow k^{1 / p}, a \mapsto a^{1 / p}$ of fields.

Remark 1.1. Recall that the Hopf algebras form a category anti-isomorphic to the category of affine group schemes. Let $\mathfrak{G}=\operatorname{Spec} H$ be the affine group scheme corresponding to $H$.
(1) Condition (a) is restated so that
(a) Given an algebra $R$ and a nilpotent ideal $I$ of $R$, the group map

$$
\mathfrak{G}(R) \rightarrow \mathfrak{G}(R / I)
$$

associated with the projection $R \rightarrow R / I$ is surjective.
(2) A right (resp., left) $H$-comodule algebra is identified with a left (resp., right) $\mathfrak{G}$-equivariant algebra. A right $H$-comodule (or left $\mathfrak{G}$-equivariant) algebra turns into a left (resp., right) one by twisting the coaction through the antipode of $H$ (resp., the action through the inverse of $\mathfrak{G}$ ), and vise versa. Under the resulting one-to-one correspondence, $H$ corresponds to $H$, itself. Therefore, as for (b), $H$ is $H$-smooth as a right $H$-comodule algebra if and only if it is so as a left $H$-comodule algebra.
(3) By a similar reason, as for (c), $H$ is coflat as a right $Q$-comodule if and only if it is so as a left $Q$-comodule. Recall that every closed subgroup scheme $\mathfrak{S}$ of $\mathfrak{G}$ is uniquely in the form $\mathfrak{S}=\operatorname{Spec} Q$, where $Q$ is a quotient Hopf algebra of $H$. It is known (see [25, p.452], [8, Theorem 2 and the following Remark]) that the equivalent coflatness conditions above are equivalent to saying that the quotient sheaf $\mathfrak{G} / \mathfrak{S}$ in the fpqc topology is an affine scheme; see also Remark 2.8 below.

The first main theorem is the following.
Theorem 1.2. We have the following:

(1) If char $k=0$, every Hopf algebra $H$ satisfies Conditions (a)-(e) above.
(2) If char $k>0$, the Conditions (a)-(f) are equivalent to each other.

Suppose char $k=0$. It is well known that every Hopf algebra satisfies (e), and in addition, (a) at least when it is of finite type; see Section 3.1.

Suppose char $k=p>0$. Then there exist many Hopf algebras that do not satisfy the conditions; in particular, there are known simple examples of Hopf algebras which are reduced, but not geometrically reduced, see [27, Remark 39.8.5], for example. It is proved by Takeuchi [26, Proposition 1.9] that (f) $\Rightarrow$ (a) $\Rightarrow$ (d), and these conditions are equivalent to each other in case $H$ is of finite type. Likely, it has been long unknown whether they are equivalent in general. It is also proved by [26, Corollary 1.6] that every Hopf algebra that satisfies (f) has a certain stronger smoothness property; the result will be proved by Theorem 1.4 (2) below in a generalized situation, see Section 1.4.

Theorem 1.2 will be proved in Section 3. It is after we prove the equivalence of Conditions (a)-(d) for Hopf algebras in a general category with appropriate properties; more details will be found in the following subsection.
1.2. Smoothness of Hopf algebras in categories. Let $\mathscr{C}$ be a symmetric monoidal category satisfying the assumptions:
(I) $\mathscr{C}$ is, as a category, semisimple abelian, i.e., abelian and every object is a coproduct of simple objects, and
(II) the tensor-product functor is bi-additive, which is then necessarily exact by (I).

The category Vec of vector spaces is an obvious example of $\mathscr{C}$. Conditions (a)(d) concerning Hopf algebras in Vec make sense more generally for those Hopf algebras in $\mathscr{C}$ which are commutative by assumption; this will be verified in detail in the paragraph following Proposition 2.7. The second main theorem is the following.

Theorem 1.3. For a Hopf algebra $H$ in $\mathscr{C}$, Conditions (a)-(d) are equivalent to each other.

This will be proved in the following Section 2. One will see that among the conditions, a key is (b), the equivariant smoothness; the background of the notion will be seen in the following subsection. Important is the fact that Condition (b) is equivalent to saying that for every object $X$ of $\mathscr{C}$, the symmetric 2nd Hochschild cohomology (constructed in $\mathscr{C}$ ) of $H$ with coefficients in $X$ vanishes,

$$
H_{x}^{2}(H, X)_{\mathscr{C}}=0
$$

where $X$ is regarded as a trivial $H$-module through the counit of $H$.
As was mentioned above, we will prove the first main theorem, Theorem 1.2, after proving (and by using) the second one, Theorem 1.3. A point to prove Part 2 (the positive characteristic case) of Theorem 1.2 is to show that the above cohomologyvanishing condition for finite-type (ordinary) Hopf algebras implies the same condition for Hopf algebras in general. This will be shown by proving that the restriction map for symmetric 2nd Hochschild cohomologies (constructed in Vec)

$$
\text { res : } H_{x}^{2}(H, k) \rightarrow H_{x}^{2}(J, k)
$$

is surjective, where $H$ is an ordinary Hopf algebra, and $J$ is a Hopf subalgebra of $H$; see Proposition 3.3. The proof depends on the fact that the 2 nd cohomology

in question is naturally isomorphic to the 1st André-Quillen cohomology, and uses some results on the latter cohomology that include substantial ones by Avramov [2].
1.3. Background around the equivariant smoothness. The notion of $H$-crossed products, where $H$ is a not necessary commutative ordinary Hopf algebra, was introduced by Blattner et al. [4]; it generalizes group crossed products, for which $H$ is a group algebra as a special case. To be more explicit, an $H$-crossed product, $R \rtimes_{\sigma} H$, over a (not necessarily commutative) algebra $R$ is constructed on the $H$-comodule $R \otimes H$, subject to an action (in a weak sense) by $H$ on $R$ and a Hopf 2-cocycle $\sigma: H \otimes H \rightarrow R$. As was shown by Doi et al. [9], the $H$-crossed products are intrinsically characterized as $H$-cleft extensions, i.e., $H$-comodule algebras with invertible (with respect to the convolution-product) $H$-colinear map from $H$. The second-named author [12] pointed out (in fact, in the dual situation) that if the $R$ has an augmentation $R \rightarrow k$ with square-zero kernel, the augmented $H$-cleft extensions over $R$ are classified by the 2 nd Hochschild cohomologies. As a result it was essentially proved by [12, Theorem 4.1] (see also [16, Theorem 1.2, Proposition 1.10]) that if $H$ is smooth, then it is $H$-smooth in the present words; the converse holds, as well, but this is rather easy, as will be seen in Proposition 2.9 (modified into the non-commutative situation); see also [17, Proposition 3.19]. The last mentioned result of [12] was re-proved by Ardizonni et al. [1, Theorem 5.9 a)] based on categorical observation using the notion of (co)separability. We reach cohomologies directly (not through augmented cleft extensions), and deduce a key implication, (a) $\Rightarrow(\mathrm{d})$, of Theorem 1.3 from an isomorphism of the relevant cohomologies; see Proposition 2.5.

Nevertheless, it is a useful method of computing 2nd Hochschild cohomologies of a Hopf algebra $H$ to classify the corresponding augmented $H$-cleft extensions, as was shown in [14] in the case where $H$ is the quantized universal enveloping algebra. In the present situation in which the relevant (Hopf) algebras are supposed to be commutative, we discuss, as was mentioned above, the symmetric 2nd Hochschild cohomology $H_{2}^{2}(H, k)$ with coefficients in the trivial $H$-module $k$, which is precisely in one-to-one correspondence with the set of the isomorphism classes of all (commutative) augmented $H$-cleft extension over the algebra $k[T] /\left(T^{2}\right)$ of dual numbers. This is the topic of Section 4. Section 4.1 reviews the above-mentioned one-to-one correspondence. It is applied, in the following two subsections, to compute $H_{2}^{2}(H, k)$ of some examples of Hopf algebras $H$ in positive characteristic. In Section 4.2, $H$ is supposed to be the Hopf algebra given in [26, Example 1.7] which is generated by an $\infty$-sequence of primitive elements. In Section $4.3, H$ is supposed to be a finite-type group algebra, and the surjectivity of the restriction map (1.2) for such an $H$ is verified by explicit computation.
1.4. Stronger smoothness properties. Beside the obvious Vec, the category $\mathscr{C}$ discussed in Section 1.2 has as examples,

$$
\text { sVec } \text { and } \operatorname{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}
$$

which denote the category of super-vector spaces and the ind-completion of the Verlinde category $\operatorname{Ver}_{p}$ in positive characteristic $p$ (see [21], [28]), respectively. These categories and the associated tensor-product functors are $k$-linear, where $k$ denotes the base field. Both naturally include Vec as a symmetric monoidal full

subcategory. Recently, they are attracting attention due to the following remarkable results which assume that $k$ is algebraically closed: in case char $k=0$, Deligne [6] proved that every $k$-linear artinian rigid symmetric monoidal category $\mathscr{T}$, such that (i) the tensor-product functor is $k$-bilinear, (ii) the unit object is simple, and (iii) $\mathscr{T}$ has moderate growth, has a fiber functor into the category svec of finitedimensional super-vector spaces, whence it is equivalent to the category of comodules in svec over some Hopf algebra in sVec; in case char $k=p>0$, Coulembier et al. [5] proved that the analogous conclusion in which svec is replaced by $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}$ holds, if (and only if) (iv) $\mathscr{T}$ is Frobenius and exact, in addition. Here are remarks: sVec is the ind-completion svec ${ }^{\text {ind }}$ of svec; Condition (iv) is necessarily satisfied if $\mathscr{T}$ is semisimple.

We will show that Hopf algebras, which are commutative by assumption, in these categories have some properties stronger than smoothness. The familiar words "(Hopf) superalgebras" meaning (Hopf) algebras in sVec will not be used in this paper. Algebras of sVec in char $k=2$ are supposed to satisfy the assumption that every even element is central and every odd element is square-zero, which is stronger than the (super-)commutativity. For $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$, we assume that $k$ is an algebraically closed field of characteristic $p>0$. Since $\mathrm{Ver}_{2}^{\text {ind }}=\mathrm{Vec}$ and $\mathrm{Ver}_{3}^{\text {ind }}=\mathrm{sVec}$, as is shown in [21, Example 3.2], we assume $p \geq 5$, in addition. Then, $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$ includes properly sVec as a symmetric monoidal full subcategory.

The third main theorem is the following.
Theorem 1.4. We have the following.
(1) Assume char $k=0$. Let $H$ be a Hopf algebra in sVec. Given an algebra $R$ in sVec and its nil ideal I, i.e., an ideal consisting of nilpotent elements, every algebra morphism $H \rightarrow R / I$ can lift to some algebra morphism $H \rightarrow$ $R$.
(2) Assume char $k=p>0$, and let us work in sVec or $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$. Let $H$ be a Hopf algebra in the category, such that the naturally associated, ordinary quotient Hopf algebra $\bar{H}$ (see (5.1), (5.5)) is smooth. Given an algebra $R$ and a bounded nil ideal I of $R$, every algebra morphism $H \rightarrow R / I$ can lift to some algebra morphism $H \rightarrow R$.

The conclusions above are restated so that the group map $\mathfrak{G}(R) \rightarrow \mathfrak{G}(R / I)$ analogous to (1.1) is surjective, where $\mathfrak{G}=\operatorname{Spec} H$ denotes the affine group scheme corresponding to $H$, i.e., the group-valued functor which is defined on the category of algebras in the respective category, and is represented by $H$.

As for Part 2, an ideal $I$ is said to be bounded nil, if there is an integer $n>0$ satisfying the condition: $X^{n}=0$ for every simple sub-object $X$ of $I$. In sVec in arbitrary characteristic, an ideal $I$ of an algebra $R$ is (bounded) nil if and only if in the even component $R_{0}$ of $R$, which is an ordinary algebra, the ideal $I_{0}$ of $R_{0}$ is (bounded) nil. In $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$, the situation is the same; see the third paragraph of Section 3.2.

These situations, combined with the tensor product decomposition of a Hopf algebra in the category (see (5.2), (5.6)), allow us reduce the proof of Theorem 1.4 to the case where the category is Vec. The proof will be given in Section 5. Crucial for the proof of Part 2 is Takeuchi's result [26, Corollary 1.6] which was referred to in Section 1.1 and is now explicitly stated: an ordinary Hopf algebra in positive characteristic which satisfies Condition (f) has the stronger smoothness property

which is an obvious analogue in Vec of the one stated in Part 2. Example 1.7 of [26], which was also referred to before, shows that Part 2 cannot be strengthen with "bounded nil" relaxed to "nil" as in Part 1; see the first paragraph of Section 4.2.

The same idea as proving Part 1 will be used in the Appendix, to give a simple proof of the known result that in Vec, every torsor under an affine group scheme over an algebraically closed field is trivial. Recently, Wibmer [31] gave an elementary proof to it, but ours would be simpler. We remark that the result holds more generally in sVec and in $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}^{\mathrm{ind}}$; see Remark A.2.

Remark 1.5. We do not know whether the equivariant analogue of Theorem 1.4, which replaces "algebras" with " $H$-comodule algebras", is true. One sees from the proof of Proposition 2.9 that the analogue is a stronger statement, i.e., it implies the theorem.

# 2. Proof of Theorem 1.3 

To prove Theorem 1.3, we let $\mathscr{C}$ be a symmetric monoidal category such that (I) $\mathscr{C}$ is semisimple abelian, and (II) the tensor-product functor is bi-additive, as in Section 1.2. Concerning (I), what is actually needed in this section is the property of $\mathscr{C}$ that it is split, i.e., every short exact sequence is split; indeed, this property is weaker than the semisimplicity. The tensor product, the unit object and the symmetry of $\mathscr{C}$ will be denoted by $\otimes, \mathbf{I}$ and

$$
c_{X, Y}: X \otimes Y \xrightarrow{\simeq} Y \otimes X, \quad X, Y \in \mathscr{C}
$$

respectively. The unit or associativity constraints, when they are recognized from the context, are presented as identity morphisms.

In what follows, all (Hopf) algebras in $\mathscr{C}$ are supposed to be commutative, unless otherwise stated. Let $A$ be an algebra in $\mathscr{C}$; the product and the unit will be denoted by $m_{A}: A \otimes A \rightarrow A$ and $u_{A}: \mathbf{1} \rightarrow A$, respectively. By an $A$-module we mean a left $A$-module $M$ in $\mathscr{C}$. It is naturally identified with a right $A$-module so that
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)
commutes; here and in what follows, $a_{M}$ (resp., $a_{M}^{\prime}$ ) denotes the left (resp., right) $A$-action on $M$. In addition, $M$ is regarded as an $(A, A)$-bimodule with the special property that the left and the right $A$-actions are identified as above.

A square-zero extension of $A$ is an algebra $E$ of $\mathscr{C}$, equipped with an algebra morphism $p: E \rightarrow A$, which is epic as a morphism of $\mathscr{C}$, and is such that the kernel $\operatorname{Ker} p$ is square-zero, $(\operatorname{Ker} p)^{2}=0$. The last condition ensures that $\operatorname{Ker} p$ naturally turns into an $A$-module through $p$. Two square-zero extensions, $(E, p)$ and $\left(E^{\prime}, p^{\prime}\right)$, of $A$ are said to be isomorphic, if there is an algebra isomorphism $E \rightarrow E^{\prime}$ compatible with $p$ and $p^{\prime}$.

Given an $A$-module $M$, a Hochschild extension of $A$ by $M$ is a short exact sequence

$$
\langle E\rangle: 0 \rightarrow M \xrightarrow{i} E \xrightarrow{p} A \rightarrow 0
$$

in $\mathscr{C}$ such that $(E, p)$ is a square-zero extension of $A$, and the isomorphism $i: M \rightarrow$ Ker $p$ is $A$-linear. An equivalence $\langle E\rangle \rightarrow\left\langle E^{\prime}\right\rangle$ between two Hochschild extensions of $A$ by $M$ is an algebra morphism (necessarily, isomorphism) $E \rightarrow E^{\prime}$ between the middle terms which induces the identity morphisms of $A$ and of $M$.

By using the splitting property of $\mathscr{C}$ we see that the set

$$
\operatorname{Ext}(A, M)_{\mathscr{C}}
$$

of all equivalence classes of the Hochschild extensions of $A$ by $M$ is in one-to-one correspondence with the symmetric 2nd Hochschild cohomology group

$$
H_{*}^{2}(A, M)_{\mathscr{C}}
$$

which is constructed in an obvious manner, generalizing the familiar one in the case where $\mathscr{C}=\mathrm{Vec}$. Moreover, $\langle E\rangle \mapsto(E, p)$ gives rise to a bijection from $\operatorname{Ext}(A, M)_{\mathscr{C}}$ to the set of all isomorphism classes of the square-zero extensions of $A$ with kernel isomorphic to $M$. The zero cohomology class in $H_{*}^{2}(H, M)_{\mathscr{C}}$ corresponds to the equivalence class of the Hochschild extensions $\langle E\rangle$, and also to the isomorphism class of the square-zero extensions $(E, p)$, such that the cokernel $p: E \rightarrow A$ splits as an algebra morphism of $\mathscr{C}$.

Let $\langle E\rangle$ be a Hochschild extension such as in (2.1). Choosing a section $j: A \rightarrow$ $E$ of $p$ in $\mathscr{C}$, we have $M \oplus \operatorname{Im} j=E$, whence $E$ is thus identified, as an object of $\mathscr{C}$, with $M \oplus A$ through $j$, so that

$$
E=M \oplus A
$$

The one-to-one correspondence above is such as follows: the unit $u_{E}: \mathbf{1} \rightarrow E$ and the product $m_{E}: E \otimes E \rightarrow E$ are given uniquely by a symmetric Hochschild 2-cocycle $s: A \otimes A \rightarrow M$ so that

$$
u_{E}=\left(-s \circ\left(u_{A} \otimes u_{A}\right), u_{A}\right), \quad m_{E}= \begin{cases}\left(s, m_{A}\right) & \text { on } A \otimes A \\ \left(a_{M}, 0\right) & \text { on } A \otimes M \\ \left(a_{M}^{\prime}, 0\right) & \text { on } M \otimes A \\ 0 & \text { on } M \otimes M\end{cases}
$$

Let $H$ be a Hopf algebra in $\mathscr{C}$. The coproduct and the counit will be denoted by $\Delta_{H}: H \rightarrow H \otimes H$ and $\varepsilon_{H}: H \rightarrow \mathbf{1}$, respectively. We have the category $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ of right $H$-comodules in $\mathscr{C}$, which naturally turns into an abelian symmetric monoidal category with respect to the tensor product $\otimes$ and the unit object $\mathbf{1}$, just as in the familiar case where $\mathscr{C}=\mathrm{Vec}$ or sVec. Due to the splitting property of $\mathscr{C}$ and the exactness of $\otimes H$, a sequence of morphisms in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ is exact if and only if it is so, regarded as a sequence of morphisms in $\mathscr{C}$. Algebras in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$, which are supposed to be commutative, are called $H$-comodule algebras in $\mathscr{C}$. An obvious example of such algebras is $H=\left(H, \Delta_{H}\right)$. One can define square-zero extensions and Hochschild extensions in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$, just as those in $\mathscr{C}$. Our interest concentrates in such square-zero extensions of $H$ and Hochschild extensions with cokernel $H$.

Let $(E, p)$ be a square-zero extension of $H$ in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$. As was seen above for squarezero extensions in $\mathscr{C}$, the kernel $\operatorname{Ker} p$ of $p$ is naturally regarded as an $H$-module in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$. Here one sees that the category

$$
{ }_{H} \mathscr{C}^{H}={ }_{H}\left(\mathscr{C}^{H}\right)
$$

of $H$-modules in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ is abelian. In view of [22, Section 4.1], one may call an object of ${ }_{H} \mathscr{C}^{H}$ an $H$-Hopf module in $\mathscr{C}$. Given an object $X$ of $\mathscr{C}$, regard it as a trivial $H$ module and $H$-comodule in $\mathscr{C}$; thus, $H$ acts by $\varepsilon_{H} \otimes \mathrm{id}_{X}: H \otimes X \rightarrow \mathbf{1} \otimes X=X$, and coacts by $\operatorname{id}_{X} \otimes u_{H}: X=X \otimes \mathbf{1} \rightarrow X \otimes H$. One sees that the tensor product

$$
X \otimes H
$$

of $H$-modules and $H$-comodules in $\mathscr{C}$ is an object of ${ }_{H} \mathscr{C}^{H}$.
Lemma 2.1. $X \mapsto X \otimes H$ gives rise to an equivalence $\mathscr{C} \approx{ }_{H} \mathscr{C}^{H}$ of abelian categories.

This is a standard result, which can be proved essentially in the same way as proving the Hopf-module Theorem [22, Theorem 4.1.1] in Vec.

Lemma 2.2. $X \mapsto X \otimes H$ gives an additive functor $\mathscr{C} \rightarrow \mathscr{C}^{H}$ right adjoint to the forgetful functor $\mathscr{C}^{H} \rightarrow \mathscr{C}$.

This is also a standard result. Indeed, let $N=\left(N, \rho_{N}\right)$ be an object of $\mathscr{C}^{H}$. To every morphism $f: N \rightarrow X$ of $\mathscr{C}$, assign its $H$-colinear extension given by

$$
\tilde{f}: N \xrightarrow{\rho_{N}} N \otimes H \xrightarrow{f \otimes \mathrm{id}_{H}} X \otimes H .
$$

The assignment $f \mapsto \tilde{f}$ gives a natural isomorphism

$$
\mathscr{C}(N, X) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \mathscr{C}^{H}(N, X \otimes H)
$$

of abelian groups, whose inverse assigns to every morphism $N \rightarrow X \otimes H$ in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$, its composition with $\operatorname{id}_{X} \otimes \varepsilon_{H}: X \otimes H \rightarrow X \otimes \mathbf{1}=X$. The result is restated by the lemma above.

The corollary below now follows since $\mathscr{C}$ is split, whence every object of $\mathscr{C}$ is injective.

Corollary 2.3. Every object of ${ }_{H} \mathscr{C}^{H}$, which is necessarily isomorphic to $X \otimes H$ (see (2.5)) for some object $X$ of $\mathscr{C}$, is injective, regarded as an object of $\mathscr{C}^{H}$.

Fix an object $X$ of $\mathscr{C}$, which gives rise to the object $X \otimes H$ of ${ }_{H} \mathscr{C}^{H}$ as in (2.5).
Proposition 2.4. We have the following.
(1) Every Hochschild extension

$$
\langle E\rangle: 0 \rightarrow X \otimes H \xrightarrow{i} E \xrightarrow{p} H \rightarrow 0
$$

of $H$ by $X \otimes H$ in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ splits in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$.
(2) The set

$$
\operatorname{Ext}(H, X \otimes H)_{\mathscr{C}^{H}}
$$

of all equivalence classes of the Hochschild extensions of $H$ by $X \otimes H$ in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ is in a natural one-to-one correspondence with the symmetric 2nd Hochschild cohomology

$$
H_{s}^{2}(H, X \otimes H)_{\mathscr{C}^{H}}
$$

constructed in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$. The set is also in one-to-one correspondence, through $\langle E\rangle \mapsto(E, p)$, with the set of all isomorphism classes of the square-zero extensions of $H$ in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ with kernel isomorphic to $X \otimes H$.

Proof. (1) This is a direct consequence of Corollary 2.3.
(2) By Part 1 every Hochschild extensions of $H$ by $X \otimes H$ splits as a short exact sequence in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$, whence it can be described, just as the $E$ in (2.3) is done by (2.4), by a symmetric Hochschild 2-cocycle $H \otimes H \rightarrow X \otimes H$; see (2.9) below. The standard argument which connects the equivalence of extensions with the cohomologous relation proves the first assertion. The second is easy to see.

Proposition 2.5. We have a natural isomorphism

$$
H_{x}^{2}(H, X)_{\mathscr{C}} \stackrel{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} H_{x}^{2}(H, X \otimes H)_{\mathscr{C}^{H}}
$$

of abelian groups between the symmetric 2nd Hochschild cohomologies.
Before proving this we make some remarks. First, notice $\operatorname{Im}\left(u_{H}\right) \oplus H^{+}=H$, where $H^{+}=\operatorname{Ker}\left(\varepsilon_{H}: H \rightarrow \mathbf{1}\right)$ denotes the augmentation ideal of $H$. Therefore, we have the canonical identification

$$
H^{+}=\operatorname{Coker}\left(u_{H}: \mathbf{1} \rightarrow H\right)
$$

Notice that $\operatorname{Coker}\left(u_{H}\right)$ is a quotient object of $H$ in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$. We regard $H^{+}$as an object of $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ through the identification above.

Second, given a Hochschild extension $\langle E\rangle$ of $H$ by $X$ (resp., by $X \otimes H$ ) in $\mathscr{C}$ (resp., in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ ), we can and we do choose a section $j$ of $E \rightarrow H$ so as to be unitpreserving, $j \circ u_{H}=u_{E}$, by replacing it with $j+\left(u_{E}-j \circ u_{H}\right) \circ \varepsilon_{H}$. Therefore, we have $u_{E}=\left(0, u_{H}\right)$ in the associated coproduct $E=X \oplus H$ (resp., $E=(X \otimes H) \oplus H$ ) such as the one in (2.3); cf. (2.4). Accordingly, we suppose that the cochains for computing the relevant symmetric 2nd Hochschild cohomologies are normalized; they thus have some tensor powers of $H^{+}$as their domains. In addition, for the symmetry condition of the 2-cochains we use the 2 nd symmetric power $S^{2}\left(H^{+}\right)$ of $H^{+}\left(=\operatorname{Coker}\left(u_{H}\right)\right)$ in $\mathscr{C}$ (resp., in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ ). Explicitly, the 2 nd cohomologies in question are obtained as the cohomologies at the middle terms of the horizontal (so-called normalized Hochschild) complexes below.

Remark 2.6. By Lemma 2.1 and Propositions 2.4 and 2.5 we have a natural one-to-one correspondence between the following two sets:

- all isomorphism classes of the square-zero extensions $(E, p)$ of $H$ in $\mathscr{C}$ such that the kernel Ker $p$ of $p: E \rightarrow H$ is a trivial $H$-module;
- all isomorphism classes of the square-zero extensions of $H$ in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$.

To present the correspondence explicitly, suppose that we are given $(E, p)$ from the first set. We may suppose $E=X \oplus H$ with $X$ a trivial $H$-module, and $p$ : $X \oplus H \rightarrow H$ is the projection. In addition, the product $m_{E}$ of $E=X \oplus H$ is such as in (2.4) with obvious modifications, where in particular, the symmetric Hochschild 2-cocycle $s$ is now supposed to be normalized, and thus the unit is $u_{E}=\left(0, u_{H}\right)$. $$

where $\widetilde{s}: H \otimes H \rightarrow \widetilde{X}=X \otimes H$ denotes the $H$-colinear extension of $s$; see (2.6). The original $(E, p)$ is recovered from $\widetilde{E}$ by dividing it by the ideal $X \otimes H^{+}(\subset \widetilde{X})$.

Regard $H^{+}$naturally as an object of the symmetric monoidal category ${ }_{H} \mathscr{C}$ of $H$-modules in $\mathscr{C}$, whose tensor product and unit object are now supposed to be $\otimes_{H}$ and $H$, respectively, and construct the 2 nd symmetric power $S_{H}^{2}\left(H^{+}\right)$of it; this, constructed in ${ }_{H} \mathscr{C}$, should be distinguished from the one $S^{2}\left(H^{+}\right)$constructed in $\mathscr{C}$, before. denote the morphism of $\mathscr{C}$ induced by $\delta_{1}$, and thus by $m_{H^{+}}$, too.

\delta^{i}=\mathscr{C}\left(\delta_{i}, X\right)
$$

where $i=1,2$.
(2) We have an isomorphism

H_{s}^{2}(H, X)_{\mathscr{C}} \simeq \mathscr{C}\left(\operatorname{Ker}\left(\mu_{H}\right), X\right)
$$

of abelian groups, which is natural in $X$.
Proof. Part 1 is easily verified by using the fact that $X$ is trivial. The result for $\delta^{2}$, combined with the splitting property of $\mathscr{C}$, shows that the object of 2-cocycles is naturally isomorphic to $\mathscr{C}\left(S_{H}^{2}\left(H^{+}\right), X\right)$. This, combined with the result for $\delta^{1}$ in Part 1, implies Part 2.

Recall from the Introduction the conditions (a)-(d) for Hopf algebras in Vec, ignoring (e) and (f). The conditions (a)-(d) make sense for Hopf algebras in $\mathscr{C}$, more generally. Indeed, the definition of (equivariant) smoothness is directly generalized. The morphism $\mu_{H}$ is already given in the generalized situation. For (c) some comments should be made. Due to the properties (I)-(II) of $\mathscr{C}$, given a Hopf algebra $H$ in $\mathscr{C}$, a Hopf ideal of $H$ and thus a quotient Hopf algebra of $H$ are defined in an obvious manner. Suppose that $Q$ is a quotient Hopf algebra of $H$. Then $H$ is naturally regarded as a $Q$-comodule on both sides. Given a right $Q$-comodule $V=\left(V, \rho_{V}\right)$ and a left $Q$-comodule $W=\left(W, \lambda_{W}\right)$ in $\mathscr{C}$, the co-tensor product $V \square_{Q} W$ is defined by the following equalizer diagram

$$
0 \rightarrow V \square_{Q} W \rightarrow V \otimes W \rightrightarrows(V \otimes Q) \otimes W(=V \otimes(Q \otimes W))
$$

in $\mathscr{C}$, where the paired arrows indicate $\rho_{V} \otimes \mathrm{id}_{W}$ and $\operatorname{id}_{V} \otimes \lambda_{W}$. Indeed, this defines a functor, $V \square_{Q}:{ }^{Q} \mathscr{C} \rightarrow \mathscr{C}$ (resp., $\square_{Q} W: \mathscr{C}^{Q} \rightarrow \mathscr{C}$ ), which is seen to be left exact. If it is exact, we say that $V$ (resp., $W$ ) is coflat. A right $Q$-comodule is regarded, with the coaction twisted by the antipode of $Q$, as a left $Q$-comodule, and vice versa. The thus twisted left $Q$-comodule $H$ is isomorphic to the natural left $Q$-comodule $H$ through the antipode $\mathcal{S}_{H}$ of $H$. Therefore, the co-tensor-product functors $H \square_{Q}$ and $\square_{Q} H$ are identified through the natural isomorphisms induced from $\left(\operatorname{id}_{W} \otimes \mathcal{S}_{H}\right) \circ c_{H, W}: H \otimes W \xrightarrow{\circ} W \otimes H$. As a conclusion, $H$ is coflat as a right $Q$-comodule if and only if it is so as a left $Q$-comodule.

Remark 2.8. The above definitions of the co-tensor product and the coflatness (for $Q$ ) are valid for any coalgebra in $\mathscr{C}$. Let $C$ be such a coalgebra. A $C$-comodule $V=\left(V, \rho_{V}\right)$, say on the right, is coflat if it is injective, as is seen from the canonical isomorphism $(V \otimes C) \square_{C} W=V \otimes W$, where $W$ is a left $C$-comodule, and the fact that $\rho_{V}$ splits $C$-colinearly provided $V$ is injective. The converse holds when $\mathscr{C}=\mathrm{Vec}, \mathrm{sVec}$ or $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$; see (1.3). Indeed, the proof of the well-known result [24, Proposition A.2.1] in the case where $\mathscr{C}=\mathrm{Vec}$ works in the other cases, as well. For one verifies the following properties in those cases: (i) every $C$-comodule is ind-finite (for so is $C$ ), and (ii) we have a natural isomorphism

$$
\mathscr{C}^{C}(V, W) \simeq V \square_{C} W^{*}
$$

where $W$ is supposed to have finite length, so that the dual object $W^{*}$ is naturally a left $C$-comodule.

We make some additional remarks before the proof of Theorem 1.3. The category of algebras in $\mathscr{C}$ has pull-backs. Indeed, the pull-back $L \times_{S} R$ of two algebra morphisms $L \rightarrow S \leftarrow R$ in $\mathscr{C}$ is, as an object of $\mathscr{C}$, the pull-back of those regarded as morphisms of $\mathscr{C}$, and is equipped with the component-wise algebra structure. Given an algebra $R$ in $\mathscr{C}$ with a square-zero ideal $I$ and an algebra morphism $f: H \rightarrow R / I$, the pull-back $T:=H \times_{R / I} R$ actually constitutes the diagram

One sees that $(T, \varpi)$ is a square-zero extension of $H$ in $\mathscr{C}$. If $\varpi$ has a section, then it, composed with $\omega$, gives a lift of $f$. This familiar argument shows that Condition

(a) is equivalent to saying that for every square-zero extension $(E, p)$ of $H$ in $\mathscr{C}, p$ splits as algebra morphism in $\mathscr{C}$; see [30, Section 9.3.2], for example. This in turn is equivalent to
(a') $H_{2}^{2}(H, M)_{\mathscr{C}}=0$ for every $H$-module $M$ in $\mathscr{C}$.
See the paragraph containing (2.2).
Similarly, the category of algebras in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ has pull-backs. The argument above modified into $\mathscr{C}^{H}$, combined with Propositions 2.4 and 2.5, shows that Condition (b) is equivalent to
(b') $H_{s}^{2}(H, X)_{\mathscr{C}}=0$ for every object $X$ of $\mathscr{C}$, regarded as a trivial $H$-module.
Proof of Theorem 1.3. (c) $\Rightarrow$ (a). This follows, since $H / H^{+}(=\mathbf{1})$ is a quotient Hopf algebra of $H$, over which $H$ is obviously coflat, and being smooth is the same as being $H / H^{+}$-smooth.
(a) $\Rightarrow$ (d). By Proposition 2.7 (2), Condition (d) is equivalent to ( $\mathrm{b}^{\prime}$ ), which is satisfied under ( $\mathrm{a}^{\prime}$ ), or equivalently, under (a).
(d) $\Rightarrow$ (b). In fact, the conditions are equivalent, since they are both equivalent to $\left(b^{\prime}\right)$.
(b) $\Rightarrow$ (c). This follows by applying the next proposition for $H$-comodule algebras in $\mathscr{C}$, to $H$, in particular.

Proposition 2.9 (see [17, Proposition 3.19]). Let $\mathscr{C}$ be as above, and let $H$ be a Hopf algebra in $\mathscr{C}$. If $Q$ is a quotient Hopf algebra of $H$ such that $H$ is coflat as a right (or equivalently, left) $Q$-comodule, then every $H$-smooth $H$-comodule algebra in $\mathscr{C}$ is necessarily $Q$-smooth.

Proof. Let $Q$ be a quotient Hopf algebra of $H$. Given an object $X$ of $\mathscr{C} Q$ and $Y$ of $\mathscr{C}$, we have a canonical isomorphism $\left(X \square_{Q} H\right) \otimes Y=X \square_{Q}(H \otimes Y)$, since $\otimes Y$ is exact. It follows that $X \square_{Q} H$ naturally turns into an object of $\mathscr{C}^{H}$. In fact, the co-tensor product $\square_{Q} H$ gives rise to a functor $\mathscr{C}^{Q} \rightarrow \mathscr{C}^{H}$. Moreover, we have a natural isomorphism of abelian groups,

$$
\mathscr{C}^{Q}(N, X) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \mathscr{C}^{H}\left(N, X \square_{Q} H\right)
$$

analogous to (in fact, generalizing) (2.7); $f$ from the group on the left maps to $\left(f \square_{Q} \mathrm{id}_{\mathrm{H}}\right) \circ \rho_{N}: N \rightarrow X \square_{Q} H$ on the right. Since $\square_{Q} H$ is a lax monoidal functor, for which the relevant constraints are not necessarily isomorphic by definition, it follows that if $X$ is an algebra in $\mathscr{C}^{Q}$, then $X \square_{Q} H$ is such in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$. Moreover, if $N$ is an algebra in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$, as well, then the isomorphism above restricts to a bijection

$$
\operatorname{Alg} \mathscr{C}^{Q}(N, X) \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{Alg} \mathscr{C}^{H}\left(N, X \square_{Q} H\right)
$$

where $\operatorname{Alg} \mathscr{C}^{Q}$ and $\operatorname{Alg} \mathscr{C}^{H}$ denote the categories of the algebras in respective categories.

Let $A$ be an $H$-comodule algebra in $\mathscr{C}$, or namely, an algebra in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$. Given an algebra $R$ of $\mathscr{C}^{Q}$ and its nilpotent ideal $I$, we have the natural commutative diagram
