Assume that $H$ is $Q$-coflat. Then the natural algebra morphism $R \square_{Q} H \rightarrow R / I \square_{Q} H$ in $\mathscr{C}^{H}$ is epic, whose kernel, $I \square_{Q} H$, is nilpotent. If $A$ is $H$-smooth, then the vertical arrow on the right is surjective, whence so is the one on the left. This shows that $A$ is $Q$-smooth.

Remark 2.10. It is now easy to show a non-commutative analogue of Theorem 1.3 in view of the proof of [16, Theorem 1.2]. Suppose that $\mathscr{C}$ is a semisimple abelian braided monoidal category which satisfies the same conditions as (I)-(II), and $H$ is a Hopf algebra in $\mathscr{C}$, in general. The definition of (equivariant) smoothness extends to this context in an obvious manner (though one might prefer the word "quasifree" to "smooth", in view of [30, Section 9.3.2]), and we see that the following are equivalent:
$(\alpha) H$ is smooth;
$(\beta) H$ is $H$-smooth as a right $H$-comodule algebra;
$(\gamma) H$ is $Q$-smooth as a right $Q$-comodule algebra for every quotient Hopf algebra $Q$ of $H$ such that $H$ is coflat as a left $Q$-comodule.
( $\delta$ ) $H$ is left hereditary as an algebra in $\mathscr{C}$, or in other words, an $H$-submodule of any left $H$-module that is projective is necessarily projective.
Indeed, a point of the proof is to see the following: as an analogue of Condition $\left(b^{\prime}\right)$ above, the condition
( $\beta$ ') For every left $H$-module $M$ in $\mathscr{C}$, the 2 nd Hochschild cohomology $H^{2}(H, M)_{\mathscr{C}}$ constructed in $\mathscr{C}$ vanishes, where the $M$ of coefficients is regarded as an $(H, H)$-bimodule with respect to the trivial right $H$-action through the counit $\varepsilon_{H}$
is equivalent to $(\beta)$. Here, $H^{2}(H, M)_{\mathscr{C}}$ is naturally isomorphic to the 2 nd Ext group $\operatorname{Ext}_{H}^{2}(\mathbf{1}, M)_{\mathscr{C}}$ for the left $H$-modules in $\mathscr{C}$, which form an abelian category with enough projectives. In addition, given a left $H$-module $N$ in $\mathscr{C}$, a projective resolution of the trivial $H$-module $\mathbf{1}$, with $\otimes N$ applied, turns into a projective resolution of $N$.

The conditions above, except $(\alpha)$, have the variants with the sides, left and right, exchanged, and those variants and $(\alpha)$ (thus, the above conditions all together) are proved to be equivalent to each other.

# 3. Proof of Theorem 1.2 

We work in the category Vec of vector spaces over a fixed field $k$, and let $H$ be an ordinary Hopf algebra over $k$. The coproduct, the counit and the antipode of $H$ are denoted by $\Delta_{H}, \varepsilon_{H}$ and $\mathcal{S}_{H}$, respectively, as before. The coproduct will be presented so that

$$
\Delta_{H}(h)=h_{(1)} \otimes h_{(2)}, \quad h \in H
$$

By Theorem 1.3, Conditions (a)-(d) for $H$ are known to be equivalent.
3.1. Proof of Part 1, characteristic zero case. We do not assume char $k=0$ until explicitly mentioned.

The following is well known. But we give a proof for the sake of further discussion.

Lemma 3.1. Suppose that $H$ is of finite type. Then Conditions (a) and (e) are equivalent, or explicitly, $H$ is smooth if and only if it is geometrically reduced.

Proof. It is known that a Noetherian algebra is smooth if and only if it is geometrically regular, i.e., it remains regular after base extension to the algebraic closure of $k$; see [30, Corollary 9.3.13 and the following Remark].
'Only if'. The geometrical regularity implies the geometrical reducedness.
'If'. The $H$-module $\Omega_{H / k}$ of Kähler differentials is projective (in fact, free); see [29, 11.3 Theorem], for example. In general, a finite-type algebra $A$ with projective Kähler differential module is smooth, or equivalently, geometrically regular, either if char $k=0$ or if char $k>0, k$ is perfect and $A$ is reduced; see [27, Lemmas 33.25.1 and 33.25.2]. In the case where char $k>0$, apply this to the base extension of $H$ to the algebraic closure of $k$.

Recall that $H$ can be presented as a directed union

$$
H=\bigcup_{\alpha} H_{\alpha}
$$

of Hopf subalgebras $H_{\alpha}$ of finite type. Accordingly, we have

$$
S_{H}^{2}\left(H^{+}\right)=\varliminf_{\alpha} S_{H_{\alpha}}^{2}\left(H_{\alpha}^{+}\right), \quad \mu_{H}=\varliminf_{\alpha} \mu_{H_{\alpha}}
$$

Assume char $k=0$. Notice from the general fact noted in the last paragraph of the last proof that every $H_{\alpha}$ satisfies Condition (a) and the equivalent (e), whence $H$ does (e). On the other hand, Theorem 1.3 and Lemma 3.1 ensure the equivalence of Conditions (a)-(e) for every $H_{\alpha}$ (in arbitrary characteristic). In view of (3.2), it follows that $H$ satisfies (d), and thus (a)-(c), as well, by the cited theorem. This proves Part 1 of Theorem 1.2.
3.2. Proof of Part 2, positive characteristic case. Throughout in this subsection we assume char $k=p>0$.

A main subject of our argument is the abelian group $H_{s}^{2}(H, k)$, which is now a vector space. The coefficients are in the trivial $H$-module $k$. By (2.10) we have a natural $k$-linear isomorphism

$$
H_{s}^{2}(H, k) \simeq \operatorname{Hom}\left(\operatorname{Ker}\left(\mu_{H}\right), k\right)
$$

Proposition 3.2. Conditions (a)-(d), which are known to be mutually equivalent by Theorem 1.3, are equivalent to
(b") $H_{s}^{2}(H, k)=0$, where $k$ is regarded as a trivial $H$-module.
Proof. This holds since we have by (3.3) that $\left(\mathrm{b}^{\prime \prime}\right) \Leftrightarrow(\mathrm{d})$.
To prove Part 2 of Theorem 1.2, notice first that (e) implies (f). Takeuchi [26, Proposition 1.9] proves that (f) implies (d). In view of Proposition 3.2, it remains to prove that (b") implies (e). This follows from the following proposition, which, indeed, shows that if $H_{s}^{2}(H, k)=0$, then we have $H_{s}^{2}(J, k)=0$ for every finite-type Hopf subalgebra $J$ of $H$. By Proposition 3.2 now applied to $J$, the last condition is equivalent to every $J$ being smooth. This is equivalent, by Lemma 3.1, to every $J$ being geometrically reduced, or to Condition (e).

Proposition 3.3. Given a Hopf subalgebra J of H, the restriction map

$$
\text { res : } H_{s}^{2}(H, k) \rightarrow H_{s}^{2}(J, k)
$$

is surjective.

Proof. Let us consider the map

$$
S_{J}^{2}\left(J^{+}\right) \rightarrow S_{H}^{2}\left(H^{+}\right)
$$

which arises naturally from the inclusion $J \hookrightarrow H$. The five lemma shows that the map above is injective if and only if so is its restriction $\operatorname{Ker}\left(\mu_{J}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Ker}\left(\mu_{H}\right)$ to the kernels of the $\mu$ maps. It follows by the isomorphism (3.3) and its naturality that the injectivity of the map (3.4) is equivalent to the desired surjectivity of res.

Present $H=\bigcup_{\alpha} H_{\alpha}$ as in (3.1). To prove the injectivity of the map (3.4) (and the equivalent surjectivity of res), we may (and we do) suppose that $H$ and thus $J$ are of finite type, in view of (3.2), replacing $H$ and $J$ with $H_{\alpha}$ and $J \cap H_{\alpha}$, respectively. Here we remark that $J \cap H_{\alpha}$ is of finite type by [23, Corollary 3.11].

In general, for an algebra $A$, the symmetric 2nd Hochschild cohomology $H_{s}^{2}(A,-)$ is identified, through a natural isomorphism, with the 1st André-Quillen cohomology $D^{1}(A \mid k,-)$; see [30, Exercise 8.8.4]. The restriction map for $H_{s}^{2}$ is identified with such a map for $D^{1}$, which extends up to the 2nd André-Quillen cohomology so that

$$
D^{1}(A \mid k, M) \xrightarrow{\text { res }} D^{1}(B \mid k, M) \longrightarrow D^{2}(A \mid B, M)
$$

where $B$ is a subalgebra of $A$, and $M$ is an $A$-module.
Therefore, for our purpose, it suffices to prove that $D^{2}(H \mid J, k)=0$. Let $Q:=$ $H / J^{+} H$ be the quotient Hopf algebra of $H$ corresponding $J$; this $Q$ is necessarily of finite type. We have an $H$-algebra isomorphism (see [25, p.456, line 4])

$$
H \otimes_{J} H \xrightarrow{\simeq} H \otimes Q, \quad a \otimes_{J} b \mapsto a b_{(1)} \otimes\left(b_{(2)} \bmod \left(J^{+}\right)\right)
$$

where $H \otimes_{J} H$ is supposed to be an $H$-algebra through the embedding of $H$ into the left tensor factor. The base change property of the André-Quillen cohomology (see [10, Proposition 1.4.3], for example), applied to the flat ring maps $J \rightarrow H$ and $k \rightarrow H$, shows

$$
\begin{aligned}
D^{2}(H \mid J, M) & =D^{2}\left(H \otimes_{J} H \mid H, M\right) \\
& =D^{2}(H \otimes Q \mid H, M)=D^{2}(Q \mid k, M)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $M$ is a module over $H \otimes_{J} H(=H \otimes Q)$, and may be now supposed to be the trivial module $k$. But this cohomology, in the case where $M=k$, vanishes, as desired. Indeed, since $Q$ is locally complete intersection by Corollary 3.5 below, it follows by Avramov's Theorem [2, (1.2)] that the 2nd André-Quillen homology $D_{2}(Q \mid k, k)$ vanishes, whence

$$
D^{2}(Q \mid k, k)=\operatorname{Hom}_{k}\left(D_{2}(Q \mid k, k), k\right)=0
$$

See [30, Exercise 8.8.6].
Suppose that $k$ is a perfect field (of char $k=p>0$ ), and let $H$ be a Hopf algebra of finite type. Then the nil radical Nil $H$ of $H$ is a Hopf ideal, and the resulting quotient Hopf algebra

$$
H_{\mathrm{red}}:=H / \mathrm{Nil} H
$$

is geometrically reduced, or equivalently (see Lemma 3.1), ( $H_{\text {red }}$-smooth.
Proposition 3.4 ([7, III, § 3, 6.4 Corollaire]). Let the situation be as above. If $H \neq$ $H_{\text {red }}$, then $H$ is, regarded naturally as an $H_{\text {red }}$-comodule algebra, in the form

$$
H=k\left[T_{1}, \cdots, T_{n}\right] /\left(T_{1}^{p^{e_{1}}}, \cdots, T_{n}^{p^{e_{n}}}\right) \otimes H_{\mathrm{red}}
$$

where $n$ and $e_{i}, 1 \leq i \leq n$, are positive integers.

The corollary in [7] referred to above shows the result more generally for locally algebraic group schemes. We will give below a highly self-contained proof in the present affinity situation, which uses the $H_{\text {red }}$-smoothness of $H_{\text {red }}$.

Let $A$ be an algebra over an arbitrary field, which is essentially of finite type, i.e., a localization of a finite-type algebra by some multiplicatively closed subset. We say that $A$ is locally complete intersection, if the localization $A_{\mathfrak{p}}$ at every prime ideal $\mathfrak{p}$ is complete intersection. A local algebra essentially of finite type, such as $A_{\mathfrak{p}}$ above, is said to be complete intersection, if it is in the form

$$
S^{-1} k\left[T_{1}, \cdots, T_{n}\right] / I
$$

where $S^{-1} k\left[T_{1}, \cdots, T_{n}\right]$ is a localization of a polynomial algebra $k\left[T_{1}, \cdots, T_{n}\right]$, and $I$ is an ideal generated by a regular sequence. It is known that $A$ is locally complete intersection if it is regular, or in particular, smooth. In addition, $A$ is locally complete intersection if it turns into such after some base field extension; see $[2,(5.11)(2)]$. These facts, combined with Proposition 3.4, prove the following corollary in the non-trivial, positive-characteristic case.

Corollary 3.5. A finite-type Hopf algebra over an arbitrary field is locally complete intersection.

Proof of Proposition 3.4. Let us be in the situation of the proposition.
Notice that the nil radical Nil $H$ of $H$ is nilpotent. Since $H_{\text {red }}$ is $H_{\text {red }}$-smooth, the natural map $\pi: H \rightarrow H_{\text {red }}=H / \mathrm{Nil} H$, as an $H_{\text {red }}$-colinear algebra-surjection, has a section, say, $\phi: H_{\text {red }} \rightarrow H$. Replacing $\phi$ with $a \mapsto \varepsilon_{H}\left(\phi\left(\mathcal{S}_{H_{\text {red }}}\left(a_{(1)}\right)\right) \phi\left(a_{(2)}\right)\right.$, we may and we do suppose that it is counit-preserving, $\phi \circ \varepsilon_{H_{\text {red }}}=\varepsilon_{H}$. Denote the left coideal subalgebra of $H_{\text {red }}$-coinvariants in $H$ by

$$
B:=H^{\cos \left(H_{\text {red }}\right)}\left(=\left\{h \in H \mid h_{(1)} \otimes \pi\left(h_{(2)}\right)=h \otimes \pi(1)\right\}\right)
$$

and set $\left.\varepsilon_{B}:=\varepsilon_{H}\right|_{B}$ and $B^{+}:=\operatorname{Ker}\left(\varepsilon_{B}\right)\left(=B \cap H^{+}\right)$. Notice that $\phi$ makes the $H_{\text {red }}$-comodule (algebra) $H$ into an $H_{\text {red }}$-Hopf module [22, Section 4.1]. By the Hopf-module Theorem [22, Theorem 4.1.1] we see that

$$
\alpha: B \otimes H_{\mathrm{red}} \rightarrow H, \quad \alpha(b \otimes a)=b \phi(a)
$$

is an $H_{\text {red }}$-colinear isomorphism of $B$-algebras, which is counit-preserving, $\varepsilon_{H} \circ \alpha=$ $\varepsilon_{B} \otimes \varepsilon_{H_{\text {red }}}$. It follows that $B^{+} H=\mathrm{Nil} H$, whence $B$ is finite-dimensional and local.

The rest is a modification of the proof of the Theorem in [29, Section 14.4], which proves the result in the special case where $B=H$. We prove by induction on $\operatorname{dim} B$ that $B$ is in the form

$$
k\left[T_{1}, \cdots, T_{n}\right] /\left(T_{1}^{p^{p_{1}}}, \cdots, T_{n}^{p^{p_{n}}}\right)
$$

which, we understand, presents $k$ in the first induction step where $\operatorname{dim} B=1$. Recall that for an arbitrary algebra $A$, the the Frobenius map $F_{A}: k^{1 / p} \otimes A \rightarrow A$, $F_{A}\left(c^{1 / p} \otimes a\right)=c \alpha^{p}$ is defined, and it is a Hopf algebra map in case $A$ is a Hopf algebra. Since $k$ is perfect, we have

$$
\operatorname{Im}\left(F_{A}\right)=A^{p}\left(:=\left\{a^{p} \mid a \in A\right\}\right)
$$

The isomorphism $\alpha$ restricts to

$$
\alpha^{p}: B^{p} \otimes\left(H_{\mathrm{red}}\right)^{p} \xrightarrow{\simeq} H^{p}
$$

which shows $\left(H_{\text {red }}\right)^{p}=\left(H^{p}\right)_{\text {red }}$. In addition, $H^{p}$ is a Hopf subalgebra of $H$, and $\alpha^{p}$ is a counit-preserving $\left(H^{p}\right)_{\text {red }}$-colinear isomorphism of $B^{p}$-algebras, whence

$B^{p}=\left(H^{p}\right)^{\cos \left(H^{p}\right)_{\text {tot }}}$ ). We may suppose $\operatorname{dim} B>1$, which implies $\operatorname{dim} B^{p}<\operatorname{dim} B$. The induction hypothesis applied to $B^{p}$ shows that there exist elements $y_{1}, \cdots, y_{s}$ of $B^{+}$and some positive integers $e_{i}$ such that the algebra map

$$
k\left[T_{1}^{p}, \cdots, T_{s}^{p}\right] /\left(T_{1}^{p^{e_{1}}}, \cdots, T_{s}^{p^{e_{s}}}\right) \rightarrow B^{p}
$$

induced by $T_{i}^{p} \mapsto y_{i}^{p}, 1 \leq i \leq s$, is an isomorphism. Notice that $y_{i}^{p_{i}}=0,1 \leq$ $i \leq s$. In addition, $y_{1}, \cdots, y_{s}$ are linearly independent modulo $\left(B^{+}\right)^{2}$, since they map through $F_{B}$ to $y_{1}^{p}, \cdots, y_{s}^{p}$ in $\left(B^{p}\right)^{+}$which are linearly independent modulo $\left(\left(B^{p}\right)^{+}\right)^{2}$. Choose elements $z_{s+1}, \cdots, z_{n}$ of $B^{+}$which are maximal with respect to the properties that $z_{j}^{p}=0, s<j \leq n$, and $z_{s+1}, \cdots, z_{n}$ are linearly independent modulo $\left(B^{+}\right)^{2}$. It may happen that $\left\{y_{i}\right\}$ or $\left\{z_{j}\right\}$ is empty.

Notice that the assignment

$$
T_{i} \mapsto \begin{cases}y_{i}, & 1 \leq i \leq s \\ z_{i}, & s<i \leq n\end{cases}
$$

gives rise to an algebra map

$$
k\left[T_{1}, \cdots, T_{n}\right] /\left(T_{1}^{p^{e_{1}}}, \cdots, T_{s}^{p^{e_{s}}}, T_{s+1}^{p}, \cdots, T_{n}^{p}\right) \rightarrow B
$$

To complete the proof we wish to prove that this is an isomorphism. Let

$$
C:=B /\left(B^{p}\right)^{+} B
$$

This is finite-dimensional and local with the maximal ideal $C^{+}:=B^{+} /\left(B^{p}\right)^{+} B$. The algebra map above, divided by the maximal ideals of the mutually isomorphic local subalgebras in (3.10), reduces to

$$
k\left[T_{1}, \cdots, T_{n}\right] /\left(T_{1}^{p}, \cdots, T_{n}^{p}\right) \rightarrow C
$$

which is induced again by (3.11). Since $B$ and $B^{p}$ are left coideal subalgebras of $H$, it follows by $[19,3.4$ Theorem] that $H$ is flat, and hence free, over $B$ and over $B^{p}$. It follows that $B$ is free over $B^{p}$. By Nakayama's Lemma we have only to prove that the local algebra map (3.12) is an isomorphism. Moreover, it suffices to prove that the associated graded algebra map

$$
k\left[T_{1}, \cdots, T_{n}\right] /\left(T_{1}^{p}, \cdots, T_{n}^{p}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{gr} C
$$

is an isomorphism, where we suppose $\operatorname{deg} T_{i}=1,1 \leq i \leq n$, and let

$$
\operatorname{gr} C:=\bigodot_{n=0}^{\infty}\left(C^{+}\right)^{n} /\left(C^{+}\right)^{n+1}
$$

For later use notice from $\left(B^{p}\right)^{+} B \subset\left(B^{+}\right)^{2}$ that

$$
C^{+} /\left(C^{+}\right)^{2}=\left(B^{+}+\left(B^{p}\right)^{+} B\right) /\left(\left(B^{+}\right)^{2}+\left(B^{p}\right)^{+} B\right)=B^{+} /\left(B^{+}\right)^{2}
$$

To prove that the graded algebra map (3.13) is isomorphic, we make
Claim. $\operatorname{gr} C$ is, as a graded algebra, in the form $k\left[T_{1}, \cdots, T_{m}\right] /\left(T_{1}^{p}, \cdots, T_{m}^{p}\right)$.
We postpone for a little while to prove the claim. By the claim we have only to prove that the map (3.13) restricted to degree 1 is isomorphic, or in other words (in view of (3.14)), $y_{1}, \cdots, y_{s}, z_{s+1}, \cdots, z_{n}$ form a basis of $B^{+}$modulo $\left(B^{+}\right)^{2}$.

To see that they span $B^{+}$modulo $\left(B^{+}\right)^{2}$, let $b \in B^{+}$. Since $b^{p}$ is a polynomial in the $y_{i}^{p}$ with zero constant, and $k$ is perfect, we have a polynomial $u$ in the $y_{i}$ with zero constant, such that $b^{p}=u^{p}$. It follows by choice of $\left\{z_{j}\right\}$ that $b \sim u\left(\in B^{+}\right)$is a

linear combination of the $z_{j}$ modulo $\left(B^{+}\right)^{2}$, whence $b$ is such of the $y_{i}$ and the $z_{j}$. To see the linear independence, suppose that a linear combination $\sum c_{i} y_{i}+\sum d_{j} z_{j}$ is in $\left(B^{+}\right)^{2}$. Since $z_{j}^{p}=0$, we have $\sum c_{i}^{p} y_{i}^{p}$ is in $\left(\left(B^{p}\right)^{+}\right)^{2}$, whence $c_{i}^{p}=0,1 \leq i \leq s$. This implies that the coefficients $c_{i}$ and $d_{j}$ are all zero.

It remains to prove the claim. Define quotient Hopf algebras of $H_{\text {red }}$ and of $H$ by

$$
K:=H_{\mathrm{red}} /\left(H_{\mathrm{red}}^{p}\right)^{*} H_{\mathrm{red}}, \quad J:=H /\left(H^{p}\right)^{*} H
$$

Notice that $K$ is a quotient Hopf algebra of $J$, and let $\mathfrak{a}$ be such that $J / \mathfrak{a}=K$. The isomorphisms $\alpha$ and $\alpha^{p}$ induce a counit-preserving $K$-colinear algebra-isomorphism

$$
C \otimes K \xrightarrow{\simeq} J
$$

from which we see $C=J^{\alpha \alpha K}$ and $C^{+} J=\mathfrak{a}$. Construct

$$
\operatorname{gr} J=\bigoplus_{n=0}^{\infty} \mathfrak{a}^{n} / \mathfrak{a}^{n+1}
$$

This is a commutative graded Hopf algebra with neutral component $(\operatorname{gr} J)(0)=K$. The last isomorphism induces a $K$-colinear isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{gr} C \otimes K \xrightarrow{\simeq} \operatorname{gr} J
$$

of graded algebras over $\operatorname{gr} C$. It follows that $\operatorname{gr} C$ turns into a graded Hopf algebra which is naturally isomorphic to the quotient graded Hopf algebra

$$
(\operatorname{gr} J) / K^{+}(\operatorname{gr} J)
$$

of $\operatorname{gr} J$. This has the properties: (i) $(\operatorname{gr} C)(0)=k$, (ii) $\operatorname{gr} C$ is generated by $(\operatorname{gr} C)(1)$, (iii) the $p$-th power of every element of $(\operatorname{gr} C)(1)$, that is necessarily a primitive element by (i), is zero. Hence we have a graded Hopf algebra surjection

$$
k\left[T_{1}, \cdots, T_{m}\right] /\left(T_{1}^{p}, \cdots, T_{m}^{p}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{gr} C
$$

which is isomorphic in degree 1 . Here the $T_{i}$ are supposed to be primitive elements of degree 1. All the primitive elements of the source are of degree 1 , and they map isomorphically into $\operatorname{gr} C$. It follows by [22, Lemma 11.0.1] that the surjection above is injective, and is thus isomorphic, as desired.

# 4. Sample computations of $H_{s}^{2}(H, k)$ 

This section is devoted to sample computations of the $H_{s}^{2}(H, k)$ which was the main subject of the argument proving Theorem 1.2 (2). We thus work in Vec, and let $H$ be a Hopf algebra over a field $k$, as in the preceding section.
4.1. Augmented cleft extensions. We review from [14] a trick of the computation, modifying it into the commutative situation. Here, char $k$ may be arbitrary.

Fix a non-zero algebra $R$. Let $A=\left(A, \rho_{A}\right)$ be an $H$-cleft extension [20, Definition 7.2.1] over $R$. Thus, $A$ is an $H$-comodule algebra such that

$$
R=A^{\omega_{1} H}(:=\{x \in A \mid \rho(x)=x \otimes 1\})
$$

and there exists an $H$-colinear map $\phi: H \rightarrow A$ which is invertible with respect to the convolution product. We may and we do suppose that such a $\phi$ is unitpreserving, $\phi\left(1_{H}\right)=1_{A}$, replacing the original $\phi$ with $h \mapsto \phi^{-1}\left(1_{H}\right) \phi(h), H \rightarrow A$. We have an $R$-linear and $H$-colinear isomorphism,

$$
R \otimes H \rightarrow A, \quad x \otimes h \mapsto x \phi(h)
$$

This turns into an $H$-colinear $R$-algebra isomorphism, if we regard the source $R \otimes H$ as the $H$-crossed product $R \otimes_{\sigma} H$ which is equipped with the product

$$
(x \otimes h)(y \otimes \ell):=x y \sigma\left(h_{(1)}, \ell_{(1)}\right) \otimes h_{(2)} \ell_{(2)}, \quad x, y \in R, h, \ell \in H
$$

given by the (invertible) symmetric Hopf 2-cocycle

$$
\sigma: H \otimes H \rightarrow R, \quad \sigma(h, \ell):=\phi\left(h_{(1)}\right) \phi\left(\ell_{(1)}\right) \phi^{-1}\left(h_{(2)} \ell_{(2)}\right)
$$

see [20, Section 7.1, Proposition 7.2.3]. The unit of $R \otimes_{\sigma} H$ is $1 \otimes 1$ by the property $\phi\left(1_{H}\right)=1_{A}$. By saying $\sigma$ is symmetric, we mean that $\sigma(h, \ell)=\sigma(\ell, h)$ for all $h, \ell \in H$.

Suppose that $R=\left(R, \epsilon_{R}\right)$ is augmented with respect to an algebra map $\epsilon_{R}: R \rightarrow$ $k$. We say that $\left(A, \epsilon_{A}\right)$ is an augmented $H$-cleft extension over $R$, if $A$ is $H$-cleft extension over $R$, and $\epsilon_{A}: A \rightarrow k$ is an algebra map extending $\epsilon_{R}$; the inclusion $R \hookrightarrow A$ is thus an augmented algebra map. In this case we can and we do choose an invertible $H$-colinear map $\phi: H \rightarrow A$ so that

$$
\text { (i) } \phi\left(1_{H}\right)=1_{A}, \quad \text { (ii) } \epsilon_{A} \circ \phi=\varepsilon_{H}
$$

In this paper we call such a $\phi$ an $H$-section; it is characterized as a unit-preserving $H$-colinear section of the $H$-colinear extension $\widetilde{\epsilon}_{A}=\left(\epsilon_{A} \otimes \operatorname{id}_{H}\right) \circ \rho_{A}: A \rightarrow H$ of $\epsilon_{A}$; see (2.6). For (ii), one may replace a unit-preserving $\phi$ with $h \mapsto \epsilon_{A}\left(\phi^{-1}\left(h_{(1)}\right)\right) \phi\left(h_{(2)}\right)$, $H \rightarrow A$. One sees that $R \otimes_{\sigma} H$ then turns into an augmented $H$-cleft extension over $R$ with respect to $\epsilon_{R} \otimes \varepsilon_{H}: R \otimes_{\sigma} H \rightarrow k$, which is indeed an algebra map. It is isomorphic to $\left(A, \epsilon_{A}\right)$ through the isomorphism given by (4.1). Here two augmented $H$-cleft extensions over $R$ are said to be isomorphic, if there exists an $H$-colinear, augmented $R$-algebra morphism (necessarily, isomorphism by [11, Lemma 1.3]) between them.

Lemma 4.1. Let $R^{+}:=\operatorname{Ker}\left(\epsilon_{R}: R \rightarrow k\right)$ denote the augmentation ideal, and suppose that it is square-zero, $\left(R^{+}\right)^{2}=0$. Then

- the augmented $H$-cleft extensions over $R$, and
- the Hochschild extensions of $H$ by $R^{+} \otimes H$ in the category $\mathrm{Vec}^{H}$ of $H$ comodules
are in one-to-one correspondence up to isomorphism and equivalence, where $R^{+}$is regarded as a trivial $H$-comodule, and $H$ thus coacts on $R^{+} \otimes H$ through the right tensor factor.

Proof. To an augmented $H$-cleft extension $\left(A, \epsilon_{A}\right)$ over $R$, there corresponds the Hochschild extension

$$
0 \rightarrow R^{+} \otimes H \longrightarrow A \xrightarrow{\widetilde{\epsilon}_{A}} H \rightarrow 0
$$

of $H$ by $R^{+} \otimes H$ in $\mathrm{Vec}^{H}$, where $\widetilde{\epsilon}_{A}$ denotes, as before, the $H$-colinear extension of $\epsilon_{A}$. To see that this is indeed such an extension, choose an $H$-section, and construct the $H$-crossed product $R \otimes_{\sigma} H$ as above. Through the isomorphism given by (4.1), $\widetilde{\epsilon}_{A}: A \rightarrow H$ is identified with $\epsilon_{R} \otimes \operatorname{id}_{H}: R \otimes_{\sigma} H \rightarrow H$, whose kernel is $R^{+} \otimes H$, indeed; one also verifies that the $H$-section, which is identified with $h \mapsto 1 \otimes h$, $H \rightarrow R \otimes_{\sigma} H$, is a unit-preserving $H$-colinear section of $\widetilde{\epsilon}_{A}$. In addition, if two augmented $H$-cleft extensions, $\left(A, \epsilon_{A}\right)$ and $\left(A^{\prime}, \epsilon_{A^{\prime}}\right)$, over $R$ are isomorphic, we have isomorphic square-zero extensions, $\left(A, \widetilde{\epsilon}_{A}\right)$ and $\left(A^{\prime}, \widetilde{\epsilon}_{A^{\prime}}\right)$, of $H$ in $\mathrm{Vec}^{H}$, whence the corresponding Hochschild extensions are equivalent.

Conversely, given a Hochschild extension

$$
0 \rightarrow R^{+} \otimes H \xrightarrow{i} A \xrightarrow{p} H \rightarrow 0
$$

of $H$ by $R^{+} \otimes H$ in $\mathrm{Vec}^{H}$, one sees that a unit-preserving $H$-colinear section $j$ of $p$ is necessarily invertible (in $\operatorname{Hom}(H, A)$, since it is so modulo the square-zero ideal $\operatorname{Hom}\left(H, R^{+} A\right)$ ). Moreover, we have $A^{\mathrm{co} H}=R^{+} \oplus k=R$, and $\left(A, \varepsilon_{H} \circ p\right)$ is an augmented $H$-cleft extension over $R$ with an $H$-section $j$. Clearly, mutually equivalent such Hochschild extensions give rise to mutually isomorphic augmented $H$-cleft extensions over $R$.

For $\left(A, \varepsilon_{H} \circ p\right)$ as above, the corresponding Hochschild extension is the given one (4.5). Conversely, the Hochschild extension in the form (4.4) gives rise to $\left(A, \epsilon_{A}\right)$.

In view of Proposition 2.5, it follows that the set of all isomorphism classes of the augmented $H$-cleft extensions over $R$ is in one-to-one correspondence with $H_{s}^{2}\left(H, R^{+}\right)$. Since we are interested in the case where $R^{+}$is one-dimensional, we choose as $R$ the algebra

$$
k[\tau]=k[T] /\left(T^{2}\right)
$$

of dual numbers, in which we have set $\tau:=T \bmod \left(T^{2}\right)$. This is augmented with respect to the natural projection $\epsilon_{k[\tau]}: k[\tau] \rightarrow k[\tau] /(\tau)=k$, and the augmentation ideal $k[\tau]^{+}=k \tau$ is one-dimensional, indeed.

For this $k[\tau]$ we have the following.
Proposition 4.2 (see [14, Proposition 1.9 (2)]). There is a natural one-to-one correspondence between

- the set of all isomorphism classes of the augmented $H$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$, and
- $H_{s}^{2}(H, k)$.

Given an augmented $H$-cleft extension $\left(A, \epsilon_{A}\right)$ over $k[\tau]$, choose an $H$-section $\phi: H \rightarrow A$. We have the Hochschild extension given in (4.4), in which $\overline{\epsilon_{A}}$ has $\phi$ as a unit-preserving $H$-colinear section. In view of (2.9) (see the description of the product $m_{\bar{E}}$ on $H \otimes H$ ), we see that there uniquely arises a normalized symmetric Hochschild 2-cocycle $s: H \otimes H \rightarrow k$ such that

$$
\phi(h) \phi(\ell)=\phi(h \ell)+s\left(h_{(1)}, \ell_{(1)}\right) \tau \phi\left(h_{(2)} \ell_{(2)}\right), \quad h, \ell \in H
$$

The cohomology class of $s$ in $H_{s}^{2}(H, k)$ corresponds to the isomorphism class of $\left(A, \epsilon_{A}\right)$.

Remark 4.3. For non-commutative $H$-comodule algebras, the notion of an augmented $H$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$ is defined without any change. The last cited result [12, Proposition 1.9 (2)] tells, in fact, that the one-to-one correspondence given in Proposition 4.2 extends to a one-to-one correspondence between

- the set of all isomorphism classes of those non-commutative augmented $H$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$ which are central, i.e., including $k[\tau]$ in their centers, and
- the 2nd Hochschild cohomology $H^{2}(H, k)$ with coefficients in the trivial $H$-module $k$.

4.2. Sample 1: $H$ is an example from [26]. In this subsection we suppose char $k=$ $p>0$, and let $H$ be the Hopf algebra given in [26, Example 1.7], denoted by $\bar{A}$. Thus, $H$ is, as an algebra, generated by an $\infty$-sequence of elements, $y_{1}, y_{2}, \cdots, y_{i}, \cdots$, and is defined by the relations

$$
y_{1}^{p}=y_{2}^{p^{2}}=\cdots=y_{i}^{p^{i}}=\cdots
$$

This is indeed an Hopf algebra, in which $y_{i}$ are all primitive, $\Delta_{H}\left(y_{i}\right)=y_{i} \otimes 1+$ $1 \otimes y_{i}$. It is shown in the cited example that $H_{\text {red }}$ is a smooth Hopf algebra, and the projection $H \rightarrow H_{\text {red }}$ with nil (but not bounded nil) kernel does not split as an algebra map.

One sees that $H$ has a linear basis,

$$
y_{1}^{e_{1}} y_{2}^{e_{2}} \cdots y_{i}^{e_{i}} \cdots
$$

where the exponents $e_{i}$ range so that
(i) $e_{1} \geq 0$, (ii) $0 \leq e_{i}<p^{i}$ for $i \geq 2$, and (iii) $e_{i}=0$ for $i \gg 0$.

Proposition 4.4. We have an isomorphism

$$
H_{*}^{2}(H, k) \simeq k^{\mathbb{N}}
$$

of vector spaces, where $k^{N}=\prod_{i=0}^{\infty} k$ denotes the direct product of countably infinitely many copies of $k$.

Proof. Given an $\infty$-sequence $\boldsymbol{c}=\left(c_{1}, c_{2}, \cdots, c_{i}, \cdots\right)$ of scalars $c_{i}(\in k)$, let $A_{\boldsymbol{c}}$ denote the $k[\tau]$-algebra which is generated by $z_{1}, z_{2}, \cdots, z_{i}, \cdots$, and is defined by the relations

$$
z_{i}^{p^{i}}=z_{i+1}^{p^{i+1}}+c_{i} \tau, \quad i=1,2, \cdots
$$

A simple use of Bergman's Diamond Lemma [3, Section 10.3] shows that $A_{\boldsymbol{c}}$ has a $k[\tau]$-free basis,

$$
z_{1}^{e_{1}} z_{2}^{e_{2}} \cdots z_{i}^{e_{i}} \cdots
$$

where the exponents $e_{i}$ range just as in (4.7). This $A_{c}$ turns into an $H$-comodule algebra with respect to the coaction $\rho_{c}: A_{c} \rightarrow A_{c} \otimes H$ defined by

$$
\rho_{c}\left(z_{i}\right)=z_{i} \otimes 1+1 \otimes y_{i}, \quad i=1,2, \cdots
$$

Equip $A_{\boldsymbol{c}}$ with the algebra map $\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{c}}: A_{\boldsymbol{c}} \rightarrow k$ defined by

$$
\epsilon_{\boldsymbol{c}}(\tau)=0 \quad \text { and } \quad \epsilon_{\boldsymbol{c}}\left(z_{i}\right)=0, \quad i=1,2, \cdots
$$

Define a linear map $\phi_{\boldsymbol{c}}: H \rightarrow A_{\boldsymbol{c}}$ by

$$
\phi_{\boldsymbol{c}}\left(y_{1}^{e_{1}} y_{2}^{e_{2}} \cdots y_{i}^{e_{i}} \cdots\right)=z_{1}^{e_{1}} z_{2}^{e_{2}} \cdots z_{i}^{e_{i}} \cdots
$$

where the $e_{i}$ range so as in (4.7). One sees that $\phi_{\boldsymbol{c}}$ is $H$-colinear, and it satisfies the conditions (i)-(ii) in (4.3). In particular, it satisfies (i), and is, therefore, invertible by [22, Lemma 9.2.3], since $H$ is irreducible, i.e., $1_{H}$ spans the coradical of $H$. Since the $k[\tau]$-linear extension

$$
k[\tau] \otimes H \rightarrow A_{\boldsymbol{c}}, \quad x \otimes a \mapsto x \phi_{\boldsymbol{c}}(a)
$$

of $\phi_{\boldsymbol{c}}$ is an $H$-colinear isomorphism, we have $A_{\boldsymbol{c}}^{\omega H}=k[\tau]$. Thus, $A_{\boldsymbol{c}}=\left(A_{\boldsymbol{c}}, \epsilon_{\boldsymbol{c}}\right)$ is an augmented $H$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$ with an $H$-section $\phi_{\boldsymbol{c}}$.

Claim. Choose two $\infty$-sequences $\boldsymbol{c}$ and $\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}$. If $A_{\boldsymbol{c}}$ and $A_{\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}}$ are isomorphic as augmented $H$-cleft extensions over $k[\tau]$, then $\boldsymbol{c}=\boldsymbol{c}^{\prime}$.

Indeed, suppose that $f: A_{e^{\prime}} \rightarrow A_{e}$ is an isomorphism. This $f$ decomposes uniquely into a composition

$$
A_{e^{\prime}} \xrightarrow{\simeq} k[\tau] \otimes H \xrightarrow{\simeq} A_{e}
$$

where the second isomorphism is (4.10). The first is necessarily in the form

$$
a\left(\in A_{e^{\prime}}\right) \mapsto\left(g \otimes \mathrm{id}_{H}\right) \circ \rho_{e^{\prime}}(a)
$$

where $g: A_{e^{\prime}} \rightarrow k[\tau]$ is a $k[\tau]$-linear map which is unit-preserving and augmented. So, we have $g\left(z_{i}^{\prime}\right)=d_{i} \tau$ for some $d_{i} \in k$, and

$$
f\left(z_{i}^{\prime}\right)=z_{i}+d_{i} \tau, \quad i=1,2, \cdots
$$

where $z_{i}^{\prime}$ denote the generators of $A_{e^{\prime}}$ analogous to the $z_{i}$ of $A_{e}$. It follows that

$$
f\left(\left(z_{i}^{\prime}\right)^{p^{i}}-\left(z_{i+1}^{\prime}\right)^{p^{i+1}}\right)=\left(z_{i}+d_{i} \tau\right)^{p^{i}}-\left(z_{i+1}+d_{i+1} \tau\right)^{p^{i+1}}, \quad i=1,2, \cdots
$$

which reduce to $c_{i}^{\prime} \tau=c_{i} \tau$, or $c^{\prime}=c$. This proves the claim.
Claim. Every augmented $H$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$ is isomorphic to $A_{e}$ for some $c \in k^{\text {H }}$.

To prove this, let $\left(A, \epsilon_{A}\right)$ be an augmented $H$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$. Choose an $H$-section $\phi: H \rightarrow A$, and set

$$
w_{i}:=\phi\left(y_{i}\right), \quad i=1,2, \cdots
$$

Notice $\epsilon_{A}\left(w_{i}\right)=0$. By a simple computation one sees $w_{i}^{p^{i}}-w_{i+1}^{p^{i+1}} \in A^{\cos H}=k[\tau]$, and that this last element is killed by $\epsilon_{A}$. It follows that

$$
w_{i}^{p^{i}}-w_{i+1}^{p^{i+1}}=c_{i} \tau, \quad i=1,2, \cdots
$$

for some $c_{i} \in k$. Set $\boldsymbol{c}:=\left(c_{1}, c_{2}, \cdots, c_{i}, \cdots\right)\left(\in k^{\mathbb{H}}\right)$. Then we see that

$$
h\left(z_{i}\right)=w_{i}, \quad i=1,2, \cdots
$$

defines an $H$-colinear, augmented $k[\tau]$-algebra map $h: A_{e} \rightarrow A$, which is necessarily an isomorphism by [11, Lemma 1.3]. This proves the claim.

From the two claims above and Proposition 4.2 we obtain a one-to-one correspondence between the two sets in (4.8). To $\boldsymbol{c}=\left(c_{1}, c_{2}, \cdots, c_{i}, \cdots\right)$ in $k^{\mathbb{H}}$, there corresponds the cohomology class of the normalized 2-cocycle $s_{c}: H \otimes H \rightarrow k$ which arises from the $H$-section $\phi_{c}$ through the relation (4.6). It satisfies
(i) $s\left(y_{i}, y_{i}^{\prime}\right)=0$ for $0 \leq r<p^{i}-1$,
(ii) $s\left(y_{i}, y_{i}^{p^{i}-1}\right)-s\left(y_{i+1}, y_{i+1}^{p^{i+1}-1}\right)=c_{i}$,
where $i=1,2, \cdots$. Notice that $s\left(y_{i}^{\prime}, y_{i}^{\prime}\right)=s\left(y_{i}, y_{i}^{r+t-1}\right)$ for any positive integers $r, t$, since the 2-cosycles are naturally identified with the linear maps $S_{H}^{2}\left(H^{+}\right) \rightarrow k$; see the proof of Proposition 2.7. If a 2-cocycle $s$ has the properties (i)-(ii) above, then the corresponding augmented $H$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$ is isomorphic to the $A_{e}$, as is seen from the augment proving the last claim. It follows that two 2-cocycles satisfying (i)-(ii) in common are cohomologous to each other. Therefore, we see

$$
s_{c}+s_{e^{\prime}} \sim s_{c+e^{\prime}} \quad \text { and } \quad \lambda s_{c} \sim s_{\lambda c}, \lambda \in k
$$

where $\sim$ indicates "cohomologous". This proves that the obtained one-to-one correspondence is indeed a linear isomorphism.

4.3. Sample 2: $H$ is a group algebra $k G$. We continue to suppose char $k=p>$ 0 . Recall from Proposition 3.3 that the restriction map $H_{s}^{2}(H, k) \rightarrow H_{s}^{2}(J, k)$ is surjective, and this follows from the result proved under the assumption that $H$ is of finite type. Here we wish to verify the result directly by explicit computations, when $H=k G$ is a finite-type commutative group algebra and $J$ is its Hopf (indeed, group) subalgebra.

The symmetric 2nd Hochschild cohomology $H_{s}^{2}(k G, k)$ (resp., the 2nd Hochschild cohomology $H^{2}(k G, k)$ ) is linearly isomorphic to the symmetric part of the 2 nd group cohomology $H^{2}(G, k)_{\text {sym }}$ (resp., the full 2nd group cohomology $H^{2}(G, k)$ ). Therefore, the computational results below may be standard, or even known, for experts in group theory. But our method of computations, which uses augmented cleft extensions possessing linear structure and depends on the Diamond Lemma, would be useful.

Let $G$ be a finitely generated abelian group. Decompose $G$ into the direct sum $G=\bigoplus_{\alpha} G_{\alpha}$, where $\alpha$ runs through $\{\infty$, all pimes $\}$, of the torsion-free part $G_{\infty}$ and the $t$-primary parts $G_{t}$ for primes $t$. We have

$$
H_{s}^{2}(k G, k)=\bigoplus_{\alpha} H_{s}^{2}\left(k G_{\alpha}, k\right), \text { and } H_{s}^{2}\left(k G_{\alpha}, k\right)=0 \text { if } \alpha \neq p
$$

in view that $k G_{\alpha}$ is smooth unless $\alpha=p$. Therefore, we may and we do suppose that $G$ is a non-trivial finite abelian $p$-group. We present the operation on $G$ by addition. Let $o(g)$ denote the order of $g \in G$, which is thus some power of $p$.

Choose a system $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{q}$ of non-zero generators of $G$ such that

$$
G=\mathbb{Z} x_{1} \oplus \cdots \oplus \mathbb{Z} x_{q}
$$

The number $q$ does not depend of choice of the systems.
Proposition 4.5. We have a linear isomorphism

$$
H_{s}^{2}(k G, k) \simeq k^{q}
$$

Proof. Given an element $\boldsymbol{a}=\left(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{q}\right)$ of $k^{q}$, define $\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}}$ to be the $k[\tau]$-algebra which is generated by $z_{1}, \ldots, z_{q}$, and is defined by the relation

$$
z_{i}^{o\left(x_{i}\right)}=1+a_{i} \tau, \quad 1 \leq i \leq q
$$

By the Diamond Lemma [3, Section 10.3], this has a $k[\tau]$-free basis,

$$
z_{1}^{n_{1}} \ldots z_{q}^{n_{q}}, \quad 1 \leq n_{i}<o\left(x_{i}\right), 1 \leq i \leq q
$$

Equipped with the algebra map $\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}} \rightarrow k$ determined by $\tau \mapsto 0$ and $z_{i} \mapsto 1,1 \leq$ $i \leq q, \mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}}$ turns into an augmented $k G$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$ with respect to the coaction given by

$$
\rho_{\boldsymbol{a}}: \mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}} \rightarrow \mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}} \otimes k G, \quad \rho_{\boldsymbol{a}}\left(z_{i}\right)=z_{i} \otimes x_{i}, 1 \leq i \leq q
$$

Indeed, a $k G$-section is given by the linear map $\phi_{\boldsymbol{a}}: k G \rightarrow \mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}}$ which sends each element $x_{1}^{n_{1}} \ldots x_{q}^{n_{q}}$ of $G$, where $1 \leq n_{i}<o\left(x_{i}\right), 1 \leq i \leq q$, to the $k[\tau]$-free basis element $z_{1}^{n_{1}} \ldots z_{q}^{n_{q}}$ of $\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}}$. The associated (see (4.6)) symmetric Hochschild 2 -cocyle $s: k G \otimes k G \rightarrow k$ is seen to have the properties
(i) $s\left(x_{i}, x_{i}^{\prime}\right)=0$ for $0 \leq t<o\left(x_{i}\right)-1$,
(ii) $s\left(x_{i}, x_{i}^{o\left(x_{i}\right)-1}\right)=a_{i}$,

where $1 \leq i \leq q$. An argument analogous to the one of proving Proposition 4.4 shows that every augmented cleft $k G$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$ is isomorphic to some $\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}}$, where $\boldsymbol{a}\left(\in k^{q}\right)$ is uniquely determined, and the resulting one-to-one correspondence $H_{s}^{2}(k G, k) \simeq k^{q}$ is a linear isomorphism.

Let $F$ be a non-trivial subgroup of $G$. Choose a system $y_{1}, \ldots, y_{r}$ of non-zero generators of $F$ such that

$$
F=\mathbb{Z} y_{1} \oplus \cdots \oplus \mathbb{Z} y_{r}
$$

similar to (4.12). Then one can present uniquely the elements $y_{i}$ so that

$$
y_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{q} c_{i j} x_{j}, \quad 0 \leq c_{i j}<o\left(x_{j}\right), c_{i j} \in \mathbb{Z}
$$

where $1 \leq i \leq r$. Note that

$$
o\left(y_{i}\right)=\max \left\{o\left(c_{i j} x_{j}\right) \mid 1 \leq j \leq q\right\}
$$

Lemma 4.6. The two systems of the generators can be re-chosen so that
(i) $c_{i j}=0$ if $i>j$;
(ii) $o\left(y_{i}\right)=o\left(c_{i i} x_{i}\right), 1 \leq i \leq r$;
(iii) $o\left(y_{1}\right) \geq \cdots \geq o\left(y_{r}\right)$.

This is easily proved by induction on $q$. As for $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{q}$, it suffices to re-number them without re-choosing the elements.

Remark 4.7. By (i) we necessarily have $r \leq q$. By (ii), for each $1 \leq i \leq q, o\left(y_{i}\right)$ divides $o\left(x_{i}\right)$, and $c_{i i}$ is a multiple of $o\left(x_{i}\right) / o\left(y_{i}\right)$ by some non-zero integer, say, $m_{i}$ that is prime to $p$. We can and we do re-choose $y_{1}, \ldots, y_{r}$ so that $m_{i}=1$, or namely,
(iv) $c_{i i}=o\left(x_{i}\right) / o\left(y_{i}\right), \quad 1 \leq i \leq r$.

We have only to replace each $y_{i}$ with $\ell_{i} y_{i}$, where $\ell_{i}$ is an integer such that $\ell_{i} m_{i} \equiv 1$ $\bmod o\left(x_{i}\right)$.

Proposition 4.8. The restriction map

$$
\text { res }: H_{s}^{2}(k G, k) \rightarrow H_{s}^{2}(k F, k)
$$

is surjective.
Proof. Recall from the proof of Proposition 4.5 that every augmented $k G$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$ is in the form $\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}}$, where $\boldsymbol{a} \in k^{q}$. It has the $k G$-section $\phi_{\boldsymbol{a}}: k G \rightarrow \mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}}$. Define an augmented subalgebra of $\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}}$ by

$$
\mathcal{B}:=\rho_{\boldsymbol{a}}^{-1}\left(\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}} \otimes k F\right)
$$

where $\rho_{\boldsymbol{a}}$ denotes the coaction (4.14) on $\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}}$. As a general fact, this is a $k F$ comodule algebra with respect to the coaction $\rho_{\boldsymbol{a}} \mid \mathcal{B}$. Moreover, $\mathcal{B}$ is the augmented $k F$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$, with a $k F$-section $\phi_{\boldsymbol{a}} \mid k F: k F \rightarrow \mathcal{B}$. Clearly, the assignment $\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{a}} \mapsto \mathcal{B}$ is identified with the restriction of their associated (Hopf, and also Hochschild) 2-cocycles.

For $1 \leq i \leq r$, let

$$
w_{i}:=\phi_{\boldsymbol{a}}\left(y_{i}\right)=z_{i}^{\ell_{i \mathrm{q}}} z_{i+1}^{\ell_{i+1}} \ldots z_{q}^{\ell_{i q}^{\ell_{q}}}(\in \mathcal{B})
$$

We have an isomorphism $H_{2}^{2}(k F, k) \simeq k^{r}$ which is analogous to (4.13), and is now determined by the system $y_{1}, \cdots, y_{r}$ of generators. It sends the $\mathcal{B}$, naturally identified with a cohomology class, to the element $\boldsymbol{b}=\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{r}\right)$ of $k^{r}$ determined by

$$
w_{i}^{o\left(y_{i}\right)}=1+b_{i} \tau, \quad 1 \leq i \leq r
$$

To present $\boldsymbol{b}$ explicitly, define an $r \times q$ matrix $T=\left(t_{i j}\right)$ by

$$
t_{i j}= \begin{cases}c_{i j} \frac{o\left(y_{i}\right)}{o\left(x_{i}\right)}, & \text { if } i \leq j \\ 0, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
$$

Notice that $T$ is an integral matrix such that the $r \times r$ submatrix $T^{\prime}$ of $T$ consisting of the first $r$ columns is an upper triangular with diagonal entries 1 by (iv), whence it has an integral inverse matrix. We see

$$
\left(z_{j}^{c_{i j}}\right)^{o\left(y_{i}\right)}=1+t_{i j} a_{j} \tau, \quad i \leq j
$$

whence

$$
w_{i}^{o\left(y_{i}\right)}=1+\sum_{j=1}^{q} t_{i j} a_{j} \tau, \quad 1 \leq i \leq r
$$

As an additional remark, in case $i<j$, the integer $t_{i j}$ is divided by $p$ if and only if $o\left(y_{i}\right)>o\left(c_{i j} x_{j}\right)$, whence the terms $t_{i j} a_{j} \tau$ in $j$ such that $o\left(y_{i}\right)>o\left(c_{i j} x_{j}\right)$ are zero. Now, from (4.16)-(4.17) we see ${ }^{\prime} \boldsymbol{b}=T^{\prime} \boldsymbol{a}$. It follows that the restriction map in question is identified, through the relevant isomorphisms, with the linear map $k^{q} \rightarrow k^{r}$ (between vector spaces of column vectors) given by the matrix $T$ with entries specialized to $k$. Since the matrix has full rank by the invertibility of $T^{\prime}$, the last linear map and thus the restriction map are surjective.

Notice from (4.11) that the conclusion of Proposition 4.8 holds, more generally, when $G$ is a finitely generated abelian group, and $F$ is its subgroup.

Recall Remark 4.3, and notice the restriction map extends to that

$$
\text { res : } H^{2}(k G, k) \rightarrow H^{2}(k F, k)
$$

of (non-symmetric) 2nd Hochschild cohomologies. To conclude this section we show that this extended restriction map can be non-surjective.

Proposition 4.9. The extended restriction map above is not surjective under the situation where $G=\mathbb{Z} x_{1} \oplus \mathbb{Z} x_{2}$ is a finite group of order $p^{3}$ and $F=\mathbb{Z} y_{1} \oplus \mathbb{Z} y_{2}$ is its subgroup of order $p^{2}$ such that

$$
o\left(x_{1}\right)=p^{2}, \quad o\left(x_{2}\right)=p, \quad y_{1}=p x_{1}, \quad y_{2}=x_{2}
$$

Proof. Choose arbitrarily an element $b \in k$, and let $B_{b}$ be the non-commutative $k[\tau]$-algebra which is generated by $w_{1}, w_{2}$, and is defined by the relations

$$
w_{1}^{p}=w_{2}^{p}=1, \quad w_{2} w_{1}=(1+b \tau) w_{1} w_{2}
$$

Then we see by using the Diamond Lemma that $B_{b}$ has a $k[\tau]$-free basis, $w_{1}^{n_{1}} w_{2}^{n_{2}}$, where $0 \leq n_{i}<p, i=1,2$, and is indeed a non-commutative augmented, central $k F$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$ (see Remark 4.3) with respect to the algebra map $B_{b} \rightarrow$ $k, \tau \mapsto 0, w_{i} \mapsto 1$ and the coaction $B_{b} \rightarrow B_{b} \otimes k F, w_{i} \mapsto w_{i} \otimes y_{i}$, where $i=$ 1,2. Suppose that this $B_{b}$ arises by restriction from a non-commutative augmented,

central $k G$-cleft extension, say, $A$ over $k[\tau]$. Choose a $k G$-section $\phi: k G \rightarrow A$, and let $z_{1}:=\phi\left(x_{1}\right), z_{2}:=\phi\left(x_{2}\right)$. Then we see that $A$ includes $B_{b}$ so that

$$
z_{1}^{p}=\left(1+c_{1} \tau\right) w_{1}, \quad z_{2}=\left(1+c_{2} \tau\right) w_{2}
$$

for some $c_{1}, c_{2} \in k$. But, since $z_{2} z_{1}=\left(1+c_{3} \tau\right) z_{1} z_{2}$ for some $c_{3} \in k$, it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(1+\left(c_{1}+c_{2}\right) \tau\right) w_{2} w_{1} & =z_{2} z_{1}^{p}=\left(1+c_{3} \tau\right)^{p} z_{1}^{p} z_{2} \\
& =z_{1}^{p} z_{2}=\left(1+\left(c_{1}+c_{2}\right) \tau\right) w_{1} w_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

whence we must have $b=0$. Therefore, if $b \neq 0$, then $B_{b}$ does not arise from any non-commutative augmented, central $k G$-cleft extension over $k[\tau]$; this shows the desired non-surjectivity.

# 5. Proof of Theorem 1.4 

This section is divided into two subsections, according to the two parts of the theorem.
5.1. Proof of Part 1, characteristic zero case. We work in sVec. We do not assume char $k=0$ until explicitly mentioned. Recall that every object $X$ of sVec decomposes uniquely into the direct sum $X=X_{0} \oplus X_{1}$ of the even component $X_{0}$ and the odd component $X_{1}$. The objects $X$ such that $X=X_{0}$ form a symmetric monoidal full subcategory of sVec isomorphic to sVec.

Let $H$ be a Hopf algebra in sVec, and let $\mathfrak{G}=\operatorname{Spec} H$ denote the corresponding affine group scheme. There are naturally associated

$$
\bar{H}:=H / H_{1} H \quad \text { and } \quad W^{H}:=\left(T_{e}^{*}(\mathfrak{G})\right)_{1}
$$

Here, $\bar{H}=H / H_{1} H$ denotes the quotient of $H$ divided by the Hopf ideal generated by the odd component $H_{1}$ of $H$, which is characterized as the largest ordinary quotient Hopf algebra of $H$. On the other hand, $W^{H}=\left(T_{e}^{*}(\mathfrak{G})\right)_{1}$ denotes the odd component of the cotangent super-vector space $T_{e}^{*}(\mathfrak{G})=H^{+} /\left(H^{+}\right)^{2}$ of $\mathfrak{G}$ at the identity $e$. By Theorem 4.5 of [13] (proved when char $k \neq 2$ ) we have an algebra isomorphism

$$
H \xrightarrow{\simeq} \wedge\left(W^{H}\right) \otimes \bar{H}
$$

in sVec, which can be chosen so as to be counit-preserving and $\bar{H}$-colinear, in addition; refer to [15, Remark 5.9] for a more acceptable proof. The cited proofs prove, in fact, the opposite-sided version of the isomorphism above. In characteristic char $k=2$ (recall that then, the commutativity additionally requires every odd element to be square-free), the isomorphism follows from [18, Theorem 5.7], if one assumes that $H$ is of finite type. It can be generalized, removing the assumption, by following the above cited proofs.

Let $R$ be an algebra in sVec with an ideal $I$. Since every odd element of $I$ is square-zero, it follows that $I$ is nil if and only if the even component $I_{0}$ of $I$ is a nil ideal of the ordinary algebra $R_{0}$.

In view of (5.2), it suffices for our purpose to prove that an (ordinary) algebra $\operatorname{map} \bar{H} \rightarrow(R / I)_{0}=R_{0} / I_{0}$ can lift to some algebra map $\bar{H} \rightarrow R_{0}$, since an algebra morphism $\wedge\left(W^{H}\right) \rightarrow R / I$, being restricted to a linear map $W^{H} \rightarrow(R / I)_{1}$ that can lift to some linear map $W^{H} \rightarrow R_{1}$, can lift to the algebra morphism $\wedge\left(W^{H}\right) \rightarrow R$ which uniquely extends the last linear map. A conclusion is that we may (and we do) work in Vec.

Now, assume char $k=0$. Given an (ordinary) algebra $R$ with a nil ideal $I$, an (ordinary) Hopf algebra $H$ and an algebra map $f: H \rightarrow R / I$, we have the same pull-back diagram as (2.12), in which $\varpi: T \rightarrow H$ is now an algebra surjection with nil kernel. It suffices to prove that this $\varpi$ has a section, whose composition with $\omega$ is seen to be a desired lift.

Consider a pair $(J, s)$ of a Hopf subalgebra $J$ of $H$, and a section $s: J \rightarrow \varpi^{-1}(J)$, by which we mean a section of the algebra surjection $\left.\varpi\right|_{\varpi^{-1}(J)}: \varpi^{-1}(J) \rightarrow J$. An example is the trivial $\left(k, \mathrm{id}_{k}\right)$. Introduce a natural order to the (non-empty) set of all those pairs, by defining $\left(J_{1}, s_{1}\right) \leq\left(J_{2}, s_{2}\right)$ if $J_{1} \subset J_{2}$ and $s_{1}=\left.s_{2}\right|_{J_{1}}$. By Zorn's Lemma we have a maximal pair, say, $\left(J_{\max }, s_{\max }\right)$. It remains to prove $J_{\max }=H$. On the contrary we assume $J_{\max } \varsubsetneqq H$, and wish to show that there exists a pair properly greater than $\left(J_{\max }, s_{\max }\right)$; the contradiction implies the desired equality. One can choose a finite-type Hopf subalgebra $K$ of $H$ which is not included in $J_{\text {max }}$. Define $J:=J_{\max } \cap K$. Then, $J$ is a Hopf subalgebra of $K$, which is of finite type by [23, Corollary 3.11]. One point of the present proof is: we have a canonical isomorphism

$$
J_{\max } \otimes_{J} K \simeq J_{\max } K, \quad x \otimes_{K} y \mapsto x y
$$

by [25, Proposition 6]. Notice that $s_{\max }_{J}: J \rightarrow \varpi^{-1}(J)$ is a section.
We claim that this $s_{\max } J_{J}$ extends to some section $K \rightarrow \varpi^{-1}(K)$. This can be restated so that $s_{\max } J_{J}$ extends to some $J$-algebra section $K \rightarrow \varpi^{-1}(K)$, with $\varpi^{-1}(K)$ regarded as a $J$-algebra through $\left.s_{\max }\right|_{J}$. Since $K$ is of finite type as a $J$-algebra, there exists a finite-type $J$-subalgebra, say, $A$ of $\varpi^{-1}(K)$ such that $\left.\varpi\right|_{A}: A \rightarrow K$ maps onto $K$. Let $Q:=K / J^{+} K$ be the quotient Hopf algebra of $K$ which corresponds to $J$. We have a $K$-algebra isomorphism similar to (3.5),

$$
K \otimes_{J} K \xrightarrow{\simeq} K \otimes Q, \quad x \otimes_{K} y \mapsto x y_{(1)} \otimes y_{(2)} \bmod \left(J^{+} K\right)
$$

where the source is regarded as a $K$-algebra through $K=K \otimes_{J} J \hookrightarrow K \otimes_{J} K$. Another point of the proof is: the Hopf algebra $Q$ is smooth since char $k=0$; see Theorem 1.2 (1). By the base change property of smoothness, $K \otimes_{J} K(=K \otimes Q)$ is smooth over $K$, i.e., smooth in the category of $K$-algebras. It follows by [17, Proposition 5.1] that $K$ is smooth (indeed, $Q$-smooth) over $J$. Notice that the kernel of $\left.\varpi\right|_{A}: A \rightarrow K$ is finitely generated, whence it is a nilpotent ideal. Then we see that there exists a desired $J$-algebra section, say, $t: K \rightarrow \varpi^{-1}(K)$ which maps into $A$.

In view of (5.3), we see that $s_{\max }$ and $t$ amount to a section

$$
J_{\max } K \rightarrow \varpi^{-1}\left(J_{\max } K\right), \quad x y \mapsto s_{\max }(x) t(y)
$$

which together with $J_{\max } K$ form a pair properly greater than $\left(J_{\max }, s_{\max }\right)$. This completes the proof of Part 1 of the theorem.
5.2. Proof of Part 2, positive characteristic case. Assume char $k=p>0$. Let $\mathscr{C}$ be sVec or $\operatorname{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$. Recall from Section 1.4 the additional assumption posed when $\mathscr{C}=\operatorname{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$ that $p \geq 5$, and $k$ is algebraically closed.

Suppose $\mathscr{C}=\operatorname{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$. Let us recall from Ostrik [21] and Venkatesh [28] some basics on it. This is a semisimple abelian category which contains precisely $p-$ 1 simple objects including the unit object 1. (Compare with the fact that sVec contains precisely two simples, i.e., the even and the odd 1-dimensional supervector spaces.) By [28, Lemma 2.20] the symmetric $p$-th power $S^{p}(L)$ of every

simple object $L$ other than $\mathbf{1}$ equals zero. Given an object $X$ of $\operatorname{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$, let $X_{0}$ (resp., $X_{\neq 0}$ ) denote the sub-object of $X$ which is the sum of all simple sub-objects that are (resp., are not) isomorphic to $\mathbf{1}$. Then we have $X=X_{0} \oplus X_{\neq 0}$. All the objects $X$ such that $X=X_{0}$ (resp., $X$ includes only simples that are isomorphic to either $\mathbf{1}$ or another specific one, the $L_{p-1}$ in [21], [28]) form a symmetric monoidal full subcategory of $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$ which is isomorphic to Vec (resp., sVec).

Given an algebra $R$ in $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$ with an ideal $I, R_{0}$ is an ordinary subalgebra of $R$, and $I_{0}$ is an ideal of $R_{0}$. We see that $I$ is bounded nil if and only if $I_{0}$ is so. This is true for algebras and their ideals in sVec, as well.

Let us be given a Hopf algebra $H$ in $\operatorname{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$, and the corresponding affine group scheme $\mathscr{G}=\operatorname{Spec} H$. The analogous objects to those in (5.1) are

$$
\bar{H}:=H / H_{\neq 0} H \quad \text { and } \quad W^{H}:=\left(T_{e}^{*}(\mathfrak{G})\right)_{\neq 0}
$$

The former $\bar{H}$ is an ordinary Hopf algebra. Theorem 5.1 of [15] proves that there is a (counit-preserving $\bar{H}$-colinear) algebra isomorphism

$$
H \xrightarrow{\simeq} S\left(W^{H}\right) \otimes \bar{H}
$$

which is analogous to (5.5). Here, $S\left(W^{H}\right)$ denotes the symmetric algebra on $W^{H}$; it is an analogue of the exterior algebra $\wedge\left(W^{H}\right)$ in sVec, which is, indeed, the symmetric algebra in the category. We remark that the cited theorem proves, in fact, the opposite-sided version of the isomorphism above, replacing $S\left(W^{H}\right)$ with another isomorphic algebra $\Gamma\left(W^{H}\right)$.

Corollary 1.6 of [26] proves that if $H$ is a Hopf algebra in Vec for which Condition (f) is satisfied, or namely, the Frobenius map is injective, then it has the stronger smoothness as claimed. Since such an $H$ is smooth by Theorem 1.2 (2), the desired result holds for ordinary Hopf algebras. This, together with (5.2), (5.6), proves the desired result in general, as is seen from the argument of the fourth paragraph of the last subsection.

# APPENDix A. A simple proof of triviality of torsors over an algebraically Closed field 

In this appendix we work in Vec, except in Remark A.2.
Wibmer [31] gave an elementary proof of the fact that a torsor under an affine group scheme over an algebraically closed field is necessarily trivial; this fact is the same as the uniqueness of the so-called Tannakian groups over a field such as above. We give a (hopefully) simpler proof of the triviality of torsors, which uses the same idea as was used to prove Theorem 1.4 (1); see Section 5.1.

Suppose that $k$ is an arbitrary field, and $\mathscr{G}=\operatorname{Spec} H$ is an affine group scheme represented by a Hopf algebra $H$. Every torsor under $\mathscr{G}$ is necessarily affine, and it is uniquely represented by an $H$-comodule algebra $A$, which is a twisted form of $H$, i.e., $A$ becomes isomorphic to $H$ after some base field extension. Such an $A$ is precisely what is called an $H$-Galois extension over $k$; it is by definition a non-zero $H$-comodule algebra $A=\left(A, \rho_{A}\right)$ such that the $A$-linear extension

$$
A \otimes A \rightarrow A \otimes H, \quad a \otimes b \mapsto a \rho_{A}(b)
$$

of the structure map $\rho_{A}: A \rightarrow A \otimes H$ is an isomorphism (of $H$-comodule algebras); the isomorphism, specialized through an algebra map $A \rightarrow L$ to some extension field $L$ of $k$, shows that $A$ is a twisted form of $H$, and conversely, for such a twisted

form, the map above is isomorphic since it turns so after some base field extension. Therefore, the above-mentioned triviality is translated as follows, and in fact, we are going to give a simple proof of this.
Proposition A.1. Suppose that $k$ is an algebraically closed field, and let $H$ be a Hopf algebra. Then an H-Galois extension over $k$ is necessarily trivial, i.e., it is isomorphic to $H$ as an $H$-comodule algebra.
Proof. Suppose that $A=\left(A, \rho_{A}\right)$ is an $H$-Galois extension over $k$. From (A.1) notice

$$
k=A^{\cos H}(:=\left\{x \in A \mid \rho_{A}(x)=x \otimes 1\right\})
$$

We may suppose that $H$ is not of finite type, since $A$ is trivial by Hilbert's Nullstellensatz, in case $H$ is of finite type; see [29, Section 18.3]. Given a Hopf subalgebra $J$ of $H$, define

$$
A_{J}:=\rho_{A}^{-1}(A \otimes J)
$$

This turns naturally into a $J$-comodule algebra, and is, in fact, a $J$-Galois extension over $k$. For the isomorphism (A.1) restricts to an isomorphism $A \otimes A_{J} \xrightarrow{\simeq} A \otimes J$ of $J$-comodule algebras, which shows by specialization that $A_{J}$ is a twisted form of $J$. In particular, we have $A_{J}^{\cos J}=k$; see (A.2). Suppose that we are given an $H$-colinear algebra map $f: J \rightarrow A$. Then we see that $f$ maps into $A_{J}$, and there results a $J$-colinear algebra map $J \rightarrow A_{J}$, through which $A_{J}$ is a $J$-module, and is, moreover, a $J$-Hopf module [22, Section 4.1]. It follows by the Hopf-module Theorem [22, Theorem 4.1.1] that the resulting is, in fact, an isomorphism

$$
J=A_{J}^{\cos J} \otimes J \xrightarrow{\simeq} A_{J}
$$

of $J$-comodule algebras; see the proof of Proposition 3.4.
Analogously to the proof of Theorem 1.4 (1), let us consider a pair $(J, f)$ of a Hopf subalgebra $J$ of $H$ and an $H$-colinear algebra map $f: J \rightarrow A$. A trivial example is $(k, k \hookrightarrow A)$. The set of all those pairs, into which we introduce the natural order defined by $\left(J_{1}, f_{1}\right) \leq\left(J_{2}, f_{2}\right)$ if $J_{1} \subset J_{2}$ and $f_{1}=f_{2} \mid J_{1}$, has a maximal pair, $\left(J_{\max }, f_{\max }\right)$, by Zorn's Lemma. As is seen from the cited proof, it remains to prove the following.
Claim. Given finite-type Hopf subalgebras $J$ and $K$ of $H$ such that $J \subset K$, every $H$-colinear algebra map $J \rightarrow A$ can extend to such a map $K \rightarrow A$.

Indeed, in order to see $J_{\max }=H$, which will complete the proof, we suppose on the contrary that $J_{\max } \varsubsetneqq H$, and choose arbitrarily a finite-type Hopf subalgebra $K$ of $H$ which is not included in $J_{\max }$. The claim applied to $J_{\max } \cap K$ and $K$ gives an $H$-colinear algebra map from $J_{\max } K\left(=J_{\max } \otimes_{J_{\max } \cap K} K\right.$, see (5.3)) to $H$ which extends $f_{\max }$; the extended map, paired with $J_{\max } K$, gives a pair properly greater than $\left(J_{\max }, f_{\max }\right)$. This contradiction shows the desired equality.

To prove the claim let us be given an $H$-colinear algebra map $f: J \rightarrow A$, which results in an isomorphism $J \xrightarrow{\simeq} A_{J}$ of $J$-comodule algebras such as in (A.4). As was seen in the first paragraph of the proof, one can choose an isomorphism $K \xrightarrow{\simeq} A_{K}$ of $K$-comodule algebras, which we identify with the identity map $\operatorname{id}_{K}$ of $K$. Then $f$ is identified with an automorphism $f: J \xrightarrow{\sim} J\left(=\Delta_{K}^{-1}(K \otimes J)\right.$, see (A.3)) of the $J$-comodule algebra $J$, which is necessarily in the form

$$
f: J \rightarrow J, \quad f(x)=g\left(x_{(1)}\right) x_{(2)}
$$

where $g=\varepsilon_{J} \circ f$, or $f=\bar{g}$ in the notation of (2.6). It remains to prove that this can extend to some automorphism $f^{\prime}: K \xrightarrow{\circ} K$ of the $K$-comodule algebra $K$. Since such an $f^{\prime}$ is necessarily in the form $f^{\prime}(x)=g^{\prime}\left(x_{(1)}\right) x_{(2)}$ with $g^{\prime}: K \rightarrow k$ an algebra map, we need to prove that the algebra map $g: J \rightarrow k$ can extend to an algebra map $K \rightarrow k$. Indeed, this is possible by Hilbert's Nullstellensatz since $K$ is faithfully flat over $J$ by [23, Theorem 3.1].

Remark A.2. Suppose $\mathscr{C}=\mathrm{sVec}$ or $\mathrm{Ver}_{p}^{\text {ind }}$, see (1.3). The result just proven holds more generally in $\mathscr{C}$. To see this, suppose that $H$ is a Hopf algebra in $\mathscr{C}$, and let $\mathfrak{G}=\operatorname{Spec} H$ be the corresponding affine group scheme. Since every nonzero algebra in $\mathscr{C}$ has a field as a non-zero quotient ordinary algebra, it follows that in $\mathscr{C}$, an $H$-Galois extension over the unit object $\mathbf{1}$ is the same as a twisted form of the $H$-comodule algebra $H$. Those forms are classified by the 1st Amitsur cohomology $H^{1}(\mathbf{1}, \mathfrak{G})_{\mathscr{C}}$ constructed in $\mathscr{C}$. But this is naturally identified with the ordinary $H^{1}\left(k, \mathfrak{G}_{\mathrm{ev}}\right)$, or namely, we have

$$
H^{1}(\mathbf{1}, \mathfrak{G})_{\mathscr{C}}=H^{1}\left(k, \mathfrak{G}_{\mathrm{ev}}\right)
$$

where $\mathfrak{G}_{\mathrm{ev}}=\operatorname{Spec} \bar{H}$ is the affine group scheme corresponding to the ordinary Hopf algebra $\bar{H}$ (see (5.1), (5.5)) associated with $H$. For the complex for computing $H^{1}(\mathbf{1}, \mathfrak{G})_{\mathscr{C}}$, which is in the form

$$
\mathfrak{G}(L) \rightrightarrows \mathfrak{G}(L \otimes L) \rightrightarrows \mathfrak{G}(L \otimes L \otimes L)
$$

is naturally identified with the one

$$
\mathfrak{G}_{\mathrm{ev}}(L) \rightrightarrows \mathfrak{G}_{\mathrm{ev}}(L \otimes L) \rightrightarrows \mathfrak{G}_{\mathrm{ev}}(L \otimes L \otimes L)
$$

for computing $H^{1}\left(k, \mathfrak{G}_{\mathrm{ev}}\right)$, where $L$ ranges through all extension-fields of $k$; see [17, Section 5.2]. Therefore, the proved Proposition A. 1 implies the generalized result in the categories.

abstract:
Hopf algebras, most generally in a semisimple abelian symmetric monoidal
category, are here supposed to be commutative but not to be of finite-type, and
their (equivariant) smoothness are discussed. Given a Hopf algebra $H$ in a
category such as above, it is proved that the following are equivalent: (i) $H$
is smooth as an algebra; (ii) $H$ is smooth as an $H$-comodule algebra; (iii)
the product morphism $S_H^2(H^+) \to H^+$ defined on the 2nd symmetric power is
monic. Working over a field $k$ of characteristic zero, we prove: (1) every
ordinary Hopf algebra, i.e., such in the category $\mathsf{Vec}$ of vector
spaces, satisfies the equivalent conditions (i)--(iii) and some others; (2)
every Hopf algebra in the category $\mathsf{sVec}$ of super-vector spaces has a
certain property that is stronger than (i). In the case where
$\operatorname{char}k=p>0$, there are shown weaker properties of ordinary Hopf
algebras and of Hopf algebras in $\mathsf{sVec}$ or in the ind-completion
$\mathsf{Ver}_p^{\mathrm{ind}}$ of the Verlinde category.
